story: The revelations have been disclosed in an extraordinary Royal biography, Ninety-Nine Glimpses of Princess Margaret, written by Craig Brown.Princess Margaret had initially welcomed Diana into the family with open arms - but was quick to shun the People&rsquos Princess after her orce.In a shocking disclosure, Mr Brown claims Princess Margaret did not even bow her head when Princess Diana&rsquos coffin passed by at the funeral.He told Fox News: &ldquoMargaret offered only the most cursory of nods, almost as though she were warding off a fly.                REVEALED: Princess Diana&rsquos SAVAGE reaction to Fergie SCANDAL The Queen&rsquos sister didn&rsquot want the flag to fly at half-mast at Buckingham Palace and &ldquoscoffed at the idea of a statue of Diana being erected outside Kensington Palace, he added.Mr Brown claimed: &ldquoShe said, &lsquoI&rsquom not having that woman outside my bedroom window.&rsquo&ldquoShe was a very difficult woman.Princess Margaret held a bitter grudge against the People&rsquos Princess because she considered the way Diana publicly spoke about her orce a personal betrayal, Mr Brown said.Princess Margaret held a bitter grudge against the People&rsquos Princess (Image: )Princess Margaret was 'unforgiving' after Diana and Charles broke up (Image: )Mr Brown said Princess Margaret was seething after watching Diana&rsquos 1995 interview, in which she openly spoke about Prince Charles&rsquos affair with the Duchess of Cornwall.He said: &ldquoShe wasn&rsquot keen on others misbehaving.&ldquoBroadcasting your feelings to the world without a warning was considered an amazing kind of betrayal even if what Diana was alleging was true.&ldquoMargaret was very unforgiving.&ldquoShe wouldn&rsquot even have magazines with Diana&rsquos face on the cover nearby.&ldquoShe would turn them over. And she wouldn&rsquot let her children talk to her.&ldquoThese were all Royals living in Kensington Palace.Princess Diana was snubbed by Princess Margaret at her funeral, Mr Brown claimed  (Image: )&ldquoBut if you crossed swords with Princess Margaret, she was a very unforgiving type.&ldquoEven if Diana had lived for another 30 years, she wouldn&rsquot have spoken to her.The orce of Princess Diana and Charles, Prince of Wales, eventually went through in 1996 - just one year before Diana&rsquos tragic death in August 1997.

story: ROYAL FEUD: Camilla SNUBS Royal Wedding because of 'tensions with F...                Sarah Ferguson 'bag of nerves' ahead of showdown with PhilipAt the afternoon reception organised by the Queen, the Duke of York reportedly gave a great speech, despite fears that&nbspAndrew could draw on a list of embarrassing Royal scandals,&nbspespecially considering his ex-wife's reputation.A guest said to Hello&nbspmagazine: Prince Andrew gave a great father-of-the-bride speech, there was some great anecdotes from childhood and all the way through to current affairs.He also touched upon how the dynamics of their relationship work.&ldquoThe one thing that made me cry was the Duke, when he said he was going to do something he's never done before he went over to his new son-in-law and hugged him. He isn't a very tactile person.READ MORE: ROYAL WEDDING LIVE UPDATESPrincess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank have left for their evening celebrations (Image: ITV )Doting father Andrew helped Eugenie arrange her train (Image: PA)The couple left Windsor Castle in a silver Aston Martin driven by Mr Brooksbank (Image: PA)                Princess Eugenie has MAKEOVER before royal wedding - and she&rsquos taki...                Princess Eugenie's husband-to-be will NOT take royal title after Ro...The royal bride took the lead in the couple's two tentative kisses on the West Steps, telling Mr Brooksbank let's kiss before the waiting cameras.Eugenie, who is ninth in line to the throne,&nbsplooked stunning in an elegant and classic ivory&nbspdress,&nbspdesigned by British-based Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vo, and a sparkly tiara gifted her to by the Queen.And the bride could not hide her excitement as she walked down the aisle with her proud father Andrew before greeting her&nbspgroom, who&nbspappeared to wipe away tears at the altar.Overcome with emotion at the first sight of his beautiful bride, Mr Brooksbank, 32, told Eugenie you look perfect when the couple met at the altar&nbspduring the moving ceremony, packed with an 850-strong congregation of celebrities, royals and VIP guests.The couple headed to their evening reception (Image: PA)Eugenie looked like she was enjoying her big day as she left Windsor Castle (Image: PA)Joined by his&nbspbest man and brother Tom Brooksbank, the groom also appeared to say oh my heart, oh break my heart as his blushig bride walked towards him to exchange their vows.&nbspWhile Eugenie jokingly said why aren't you holding my hand? during the readings before the tequila salesman readjusted her ring, lipreader Tina Lannin said.The newlywed couple looked elated at the support from well-wishers who turned out in Windsor to witness the moment they tied the knot.The couple were waved off and watched by members of the royal family as they left in a royal carraige encrusted with jewels&nbspfor a carriage procession through Windsor to greet fans who have waited hours to greet them.&nbspThe couple looked excited as they left Windsor Castle (Image: PA)The royal couple waved to onlookers (Image: PA)With similar pomp and ceremony to this year's first royal wedding, guardsmen lined the steps, pipes played and bells rang for the couple's carriage departure from the castle as a newly married couple.Estatic, they smiled and waved at passersby from a Scottish State Coach as they made their way through the cobbled streets of Windsor.&nbspMother of the bride,&nbspSarah Ferguson,&nbsplooked emotional as she watched her youngest daughter start married life alongside her ex-husband Andrew and eldest daughter, Princess Beatrice.&nbspEugenie's dress features a neckline that folds around the shoulders to a low back that drapes into a flowing full length train.&nbspPrincess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank took part in a carriage procession along the streets of Windsor (Image:  )Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank beamed at royal well-wishers after marrying  (Image:  )The low back feature was specifically requested by Princess Eugenie, to show off her scars following back surgery at the age of 12 to correct scoliosis.&nbspThe dress also includes a number of symbols that are meaningful to Eugenie as motifs, including a thistle for Scotland acknowledging the couple's fondness for Balmoral, a Shamrock for Ireland as a nod to the bride's Ferguson family, and the York Rose and ivy representing the couple's home.Eugenie stunned in a Greville Emerald Kokoshnik Tiara, made in 1919 in the fashionable kokoshnik style popularised in the Russian Imperial Court, which was lent to her by the Queen, along with diamond and emerald drop ear-rings, a wedding gift from the groom, and satin peep-toe heels by Charlotte Olympia.Excited royal fans ready at the West Door eager caught a first glimpse of Eugenie as she arrived with her father in the Queen's Rolls Royce Phantom VI.The newlyweds leave St George's Chapel (Image: PA)Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank shared a kiss on the steps of St George's Chapel  (Image: PA )As the beaming bride waved from the car one woman in Horseshoe Cloister remarked: Oh, she looks stunning.In a nod to tradition, Eugenie's wedding bouquet contains an evergreen shrub plucked from the private retreat of Queen Victoria.The floral arrangement also featured sprigs of myrtle taken from the terraced walls of Osborne House, the Isle of Wight home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert.The white-and-green bouquet also consists of the sweet-scented but poisonous lily of the valley, which was used in both the Queen's Coronation bouquet and in the Duchess of Cambridge's for her wedding.Princess Eugenie's wedding live: 850 guests packed out the Windsor chapel  (Image:  )Princess Eugenie beams at her new husband  (Image: PA )It was completed with baby blue thistles, fragrant Stephanotis pips, spray white roses, and trailing ivy.The bouquet was designed by Patrice Van Helden Oakes, the sister of floral designer Rob Van Helden, who created the church flowers for the royal wedding of the ninth in line to the throne.Onlookers waved small union flags as the bride ascended the steps with the Duke of York, who at one stage moved to help fix his daugter's train.Meanwhile, Sarah Ferguson, also known as Fergie, was&nbspquick to greet royal fans when she&nbsparrived for her daughter's wedding&nbspbefore heading into the chapel.&nbspPrincess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank said their vows in Windsor  (Image: PA )Princess Eugenie and Jack Brooksbank giggled as they exchanged rings  (Image: PA )The 58-year-old, who looks radiant in a vibrant green dress and hat, was joined by Beatrice, who is her sister's maid of honour.Princess Beatrice, who is wearing a royal blue outfit by Ralph and Russo and a headband style hat by Sarah Cant, read a touching&nbspextract from F Scott Fitzgerald's classic novel The Great Gatsby during the ceremony.Sarah took centre stage at the high profile occasion&nbspas she attempts to make her way back into the royal fold following her chaotic orce from the Queen and Prince Philip&rsquos son, Prince Andrew.She was said to have been a bag of nerves ahead of meeting her former father-in-law Prince Philip, who has never forgiven her for the scandal she caused when she was caught in the infamous toe-sucking incident with oil tycoon, John Bryan.Princess Eugenie's bridesmaids and pageboys make their way down the aisle  (Image: EPA )Princess Eugenie arrives with her father Prince Andrew  (Image: ITV )But&nbspSarah and the Queen's husband put on a united front and sat close during the romantic nuptials.&nbspAccompanied by brother Prince George, five, acting as page boy, three year-old Princess Charlotte, wearing a white dress with floral belt,&nbspenthusiastically waved to the adoring crowds as they approached the chapel.Charlotte was quick to pick herself up when she took a tumble as she arrived before the ceremony.But the little princess was not the only member of the young bridal party to struggle with the steps - there were giggles when six-year-old pageboy Louis de Givenchy also fell over when he&nbsparrived at the Royal Wedding.&nbspPrincess Eugenie stunned in a dazzling tiara, previously worn by the Queen Mother  (Image: WIREIMAGE)Princess Eugenie waved to royal fans before heading into the chapel  (Image: EPA )Onlookers were besotted with Eugenie's gaggle of bridesmaids and pageboys, including future king Prince George and Princess Charlotte, who returned to the chapel for their second royal wedding this year, following their starring roles at their uncle Harry's nuptials.There was an exclamation of she looks title: Brexit news latest UK EU today deal vote Theresa May referendum no deal date
story: The BBC This Week host referenced the Tory &ldquoanger in response to Prime Minister Theresa May&rsquos controversial Brexit blueprint, which has been rejected by both Remainers Brexiteers.Opening the programme, Mr Neil said: &ldquoThe Corbynistas as positively cheering compared with Tory Brexiteers who grow glummer by the day as the Maybot concedes everything that they hold dear in the Brexit negotiations, escaping from the tyrannical customs union, ending the evil grip of Brussels rules, making warm beer compulsory and child labour optional.&ldquoBut there was a rare shaft of sunlight for them when this week U2&rsquos Bono turned up in Brussels to declare, I quote, that &lsquoEurope is a thought that needs to become a feeling and I am in service of that&rsquo.&ldquoI&rsquom told David Davis is now sure Brexit is in the bag. Or is it? Because Tory anger at the deal the Maybot is cooking up runs deep.                Top Brexiteer brands SNP as 'world's WORST LOSERS'                 Fraser Nelson SHUTS DOWN calls for Scottish independence Millionaire rockstar Bono this week called on artists to celebrate the romance of Europe at a time when the value of the EU is being questioned in an apparent swipe at Brexit.The U2 singer hailed the European institutions as both a brain working to improve the lives of Europeans and a loudly beating heart bringing them together.Bono described the Brussels institutions as a brain that is strategically working to improve the lives of Europeans, so we do largely live better lives than anyone else in the world, as well as a very big loudly beating heart.Mr Neil continued and said: &ldquoI understand that Jacob &rsquoBanksy&rsquo Mogg has a cunning plan to shred any agreement the moment she signs it.Brexit news: Andrew Neil mocked Bono's visit to Brussels (Image: BBC&bull)&ldquoAt least that would be the plan if Banksy Mogg knew what a shredder was.&ldquoIt&rsquos going to take him a lot longer with a pair of scissors.The comments follow a warning from former Brexit Secretary David Davis who said the European Union could trap Britain in a backstop arrangement after Brexit, which would result in all of the upsides of leaving the Brussels bloc to &ldquovanish.The EU has repeatedly said Britain must agree to a backstop arrangement in which Northern Ireland remains in a form of customs arrangement with the Republic of Ireland in the event that technology is not in place in time for Brexit.But Brexiteer MP David Davis said he could not support an Irish backstop that does not have a legally binding end date.Mrs May issued a stern warning to the EU in September &ndash insisting the bloc would be making a &ldquofundamental mistake to think Britain will accept an arrangement that would &ldquobreak up the United Kingdom.In June, the EU rejected Mrs May&rsquos &ldquobackstop customs system to avoid a hard Irish border, which could see Britain remain in a &ldquotemporary customs arrangement.The EU&rsquos chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier said on Wednesday: I understand those checks are politically sensitive, adding: &ldquoBut Brexit was the UK's choice - not the EU&rsquos.The DUP has threatened to vote down the upcoming Budget if Mrs May pushes on with plans to accept a number of regulatory checks between Northern Ireland and Great Britain.DUP officials are concerned that Mrs May&rsquos latest backstop proposal would lead to a de facto customs border in the Irish Sea.If they decide to take the same action on October 29&rsquos Budget vote, the Prime Minister&rsquos Government would be left clinging onto power.

title: Brexit news BBC Question Time Scotland SNP EU UK withdrawal no deal Theresa May latest
story: The young Scotsman reminded the SNP Scotland voted to stay a part of the UK in the 2014&nbspreferendum, arguing they will have to accept Theresa May's Brexit plans.His passionate speech defending the democratic vote of 17.4 million British voters sparked applause among the BBC Question Time audience.The young man said: In 2014, the Yes campaign said that this was our one opportunity to free Scotland from being at the mercy of Conservative Government policy. 55 percent of Scotland voted to stay in the United Kingdom and stay at the mercy of whatever the UK&rsquos current Government policy may be.If that Government&rsquos policy is a no deal Brexit, 55 percent of Scotland voted to be part of that.                Andrew Neil takes HUGE swipe at Bono during Brexit rant                 Pound to euro exchange rate: Sterling slips as Brexit deal fears mountHe added: If the SNP are democrats, which they say they are, I think they should accept that.SNP First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced at the party conference in Glasgow earlier this week her party would support a second Brexit referendum if entailed with a new vote for Scottish independence.Ms Sturgeon set out her plan to torpedo Theresa May's Chequers proposals and pledged the SNP would dilute the final deal or force the UK into a second referendum.The First Minister added that if Scotland voted to remain in any new Brexit referendum, it should not be forced to leave with rest of UK.Brexit news: The young Scotsman blasted the SNP's attempts to derail Brexit (Image: BBC)Ms Sturgeon continued: If that was the choice, no doubt calls for a second referendum would grow in those circumstances.We would not stand in the way of a second referendum, a so-called people&rsquos vote. SNP MPs would undoubtedly vote for that proposition.&ldquoWe would, of course, want to talk to people about how we ensure that Scotland does not end up in the same position all over again, where we voted to remain in the EU but find ourselves facing exit completely against our will.Ms Sturgeon added that independence was the end goal of a new Brexit referendum, saying: &ldquoI think we are on a journey that ends with independence.I think Brexit brings issues around this sharply into focus.The Prime Minister rejected calls for a bespoke trade arrangement for Scotland, accusing Ms Sturgeon of betraying her nation with her attempts to derail Brexit.&nbsp

title: Brexit news update Andrew Bridgen Theresa May Customs Union EU Toby Young
story: Debating Theresa May's next Brexit move on BBC Politics Live, Toby Young claimed eurosceptic MPs calling for a vote of no confidence in the Prime Minister face the dilemma of triggering a general election that could result in a Jeremy Corbyn-led Government.Mr Young argued Brexiteers MPs will be faced with a tough choice between either supporting Mrs May's Brexit deal or Jeremy Corbyn in Number 10.&nbspAs he put his argument forward, the former universities minister advisor branded Tory MP Andrew Bridgen and his eurosceptic colleagues bug-eyed.He said: &ldquoI think the dilemma that many eurosceptics are facing is if we do force a vote of confidence in the Prime Minister and she loses and resigns, in that febrile and uncertain environment a general election could be triggered and in that general election Jeremy Corbyn could end up winning.                Brexit news: UK to hand billions to EU under May's customs union plot&ldquoSo if they are faced with the choice between Chequers, Chequers minus or a Corbyn-led Government that is a tough choice even for bug-eyed Brexit eurosceptics like Andrew.But Mr Bridgen, also participating in the debate, hit back claiming he had been called worse in the past.&nbspHe replied:&nbsp &ldquoI&rsquove been called worse.&ldquoI led Leave for the East Midlands, the East Midlands voted 51 to 49 Leave.&ldquoMy own seat North West Leicestershire voted 61 to 39 to Leave.Brexit news: Toby young brands Andrew Bridgen a 'bug-eyed eurosceptic' (Image: BBC)&ldquoI started out as a rebel, I was pushing for a referendum, we had a referendum, Leave won.&ldquoTheresa May came in and said that Brexit means Brexit in her Lancaster House speech.&ldquoI&rsquom completely behind her, I remain behind Lancaster House.&ldquoIt&rsquos just very unfortunate for me and my electorate and the people of the East Midlands who voted to Leave and still want to leave the European Union that the Prime Minister doesn&rsquot stand behind her own Mansion House speech.Asked to choose between a deal that kept the UK in the Customs Union and a Jeremy Corbyn led Government, the Tory Brexiteer replied: &ldquoThe worst would be Jeremy Corbyn but I don&rsquot see them as mutual exclusives.&ldquoWe can avoid having Jeremy Corbyn as Prime Minister. I don&rsquot think people are that desperate to vote for that.The clash comes as the Prime Minister last night played down hopes of a Brexit breakthrough following growing concern over fresh proposals for solving the Irish border row.The Prime Minister admitted that next week's Brussels EU summit may postpone a decision on a Brexit deal.Brexiteer Tories feared it could also leave Britain tied indefinitely to an EU customs union under a backstop contingency plan to avoid a hard border between the province and the Irish Republic.

title: brexit news no deal free trade agreements 70 countries technical notices
story: No deal Brexit could destroy the UK's trade deals with more than 70 countries (Image: )The Government today released a further 29 technical notices detailing preparations which will be necessary to cope with the possibility of withdrawal from the EU without a deal in March next year &ndash which warns of potential restrictions and rule changes which would affect millions of people if they come into effect.The papers cover issues ranging from consumer rights to the regulation of pesticides, trading in electricity, rail transport and the trade in rough diamonds.One of the notices, on the subject of fishing rights, appears to raise the prospect of further disputes similar to the a recent clashes between British and French scallops fishermen.It states: There will be no automatic access for UK-registered vessels to fish in EU or third country waters.                Brexiteer QC claims UK will save many BILLIONS of pounds in no deal                Brexit no deal papers blasted for offering &lsquofew solutions&rsquoUK Fisheries Administrations will tell UK quota holders what their quota allocation will be.The Government will also confirm arrangements for those who fish for non-quota shellfish (scallops and ediblespider crabs) and demersal species under the Western Waters effort regime.UK Fisheries Administrations inform quota holders of their allocations in January each year and will seek to do so in 2019 to minimise disruption to fishing and allow fishermen to plan for the year.There will be no automatic access to exchanging fishing opportunities with EU member states, and no automatic access for EU member states to exchange fishing opportunities with the UK.The papers raise the spectre of more clashes between scallops fishermen (Image: )Another, focusing on copyright, warns Britons could be barred from accessing their accounts for Netflix, Spotify and other online entertainment while travelling to EU states in the event of a no-deal.Under the EU-wide portability regulation agreed in 2017 and in force since April, citizens can access accounts set up and based in one country while visiting other member states.But the technical notice said: The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU.This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation.                'All options on the table! Starmer says new Brexit vote still possible                Minister says no deal trade EMBARGO could ONLY be triggered by EUUK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU.The UK will lose FTAS with more than 70 non-EU countries could bite the dust in the event of a hard Brexit, another paper indicated.The countries &ndash which account for 12 per cent of the UK's total trade &ndash are covered by around 40 EU free trade agreements delivering preferential tariffs and enhanced market access.In a document detailing preparations which need to be made to deal with the possibility of a no-deal, the Department for International Trade said: In the event of a 'no deal', EU trade agreements will cease to apply to the UK when we leave the EU.The department said it was seeking to forge new bilateral deals which are identical or substantially the same as the EU agreements which Britain is giving up.But it warned companies that, even if such deals can be reached, there may be practical changes to the way trade takes place, depending on discussions with each inidual country.And it confirmed that if these are not in place in time for a no-deal , exports and imports to these countries will become subject to tariffs under World Trade Organisation rules.

title: Brexit news update Theresa May Chequers Customs Union Andrew Bridgen
story: Speaking on BBC Politics Live, the Conservative Brexiteer argued his colleagues are quickly coming to the realisation a vote of no confidence in Theresa May in protest of her Brexit proposal should have been called before the summer recess.Mr Bridgen, who admitted to having sent a letter of no confidence in the Prime Minister to the 1922 Committee, claimed he suspected bad news were on the way as&nbspa number of Brexiteers have allegedly been invited for lunch or dinner at Number 10 next week.&nbspHe said: &ldquoI am on the record as I put my letter of no confidence in publicly back in July, and I think we will get to the 48 letters.&ldquoWe can&rsquot carry on like this.                Brexit news: UK to hand billions to EU under May's customs union plot                Brexiteer MP's PERFECT comeback when branded 'bug-eyed eurosceptic'&ldquoI&rsquove done my bit and I would urge colleagues who haven&rsquot put letters in who will be absolutely shocked if we are stopped in a customs union, which is in breach of our manifesto pledges we only stood on last year, that they should put their letters in and let&rsquos test the Prime Minister&rsquos popularity with the party.&ldquoI think colleagues have been holding back. It would be an indulgence to have a leadership challenge.&ldquoI don&rsquot think it&rsquos going to be a coronation if we have a leadership challenge.&ldquoI think it&rsquos going to be a hard-fought election, and I think they wanted to avoid that but I think if it becomes clear that we are stopping in a customs union, colleagues will come to the conclusion that we should have had this vote before summer recess and dealt with it.Brexit news: Andrew Bridgen claims Theresa May could be ousted this week (Image: BBC&bull)&ldquoBut we&rsquoll have to deal with it now and it&rsquos coming to a head next week.He added: &ldquoColleagues are telling me that a lot of Brexiteers are being invited for dinner and lunch at Number 10 next week, so I guess there is bad news on the way.The Prime Minister is facing a backlash from Cabinet rebels over her backstop plan which they fear will lock Britain into a customs union with Brussels indefinitely.The proposals are set to be presented to EU leaders in Brussels next week.However, ministers including International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have voiced their disapproval already.Speculation is rife that there could be more resignations to add to those of Mr Johnson as Foreign Secretary, as well as&nbspBrexit&nbspSecretary David Davis, in the wake of the unveiling of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers blueprint earlier this year.A number of ministers, including Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, were said to have raised concerns during the meeting which lasted around an hour-and-a-half.In addition, Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, who was not at the Downing Street meeting, has refused to endorse the Prime Minister's Chequers blueprint for Brexit.International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt and the Leader of the Commons Andrea Leadsom - who, like Ms McVey, both backed Leave in the referendum in 2016 - were also said to harbour deep concerns.

title: brexit news theresa may eu uk no deal brexit technical notices
story: The 29 &lsquotechnical notices&rsquo drawn up by Whitehall cover areas including free trade agreements after the split, fishing policy and rail transport.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab said the Government is still striving to strike a good deal with Brussels, but added the documents showed the &ldquounlikely prospect of no deal is being taken seriously.The latest batch of documents reveal&nbsphow the UK will immediately regain control of its waters in a no deal scenario and in some areas businesses and iniduals will notice nothing change.But they included a series of warnings, including &ldquoburdensome new restrictions for UK firms operating on the Continent, possible disruption to cross-channel rail travel and the threat of power blackouts in Northern Ireland.The UK will also lose free trade agreements with more than 70 non-EU countries around the world if it leaves without a deal, the Government warned.READ MORE: Keep up to date with all of today's Brexit news with Express's live blog                Brexit news: No-deal could loss of more than 70 free trade dealsThe latest batch of documents cover:Funding for British Overseas TerritoriesAs a member of the EU, the UK and its Overseas Territories can currently apply for funding from the bloc to pay for specific projects.But if Britain leaves without a deal, places like Gibraltar could lose future funding for existing projects under EU programmes.The document released today says the Chancellor will guarantee funding for specific EU projects to &ldquoprovide certainty for British Overseas Territories governments.Commercial fishingIn a no-deal Brexit, the Government says it will establish its fisheries policies as a replacement for the EU&rsquos controversial Common Fisheries Policy.The Department for Environment Food &amp Rural Affairs says non-UK-registered vessels will no longer enjoy automatic access to UK&nbspwaters,&nbspunless there are existing agreements in place.But UK boats will lose their automatic right to fish in EU or third country waters.Meanwhile, the UK Fisheries Administrations will &ldquotell UK quota holders what their quota allocation will be.Brexit news: The Government has released more of its contingency planning for a no-deal Brexit (Image:  EPA)Today's technical notices cover what will happen to the UK fishing industry in a no-deal Brexit (Image:  IMAGES)                Brexit news: UK to hand billions to EU under May's customs union plotBreeding animalsBreeders of pedigree horses, cattle, sheep, pigs and goats will lose their automatic recognition in the EU if Britain leaves without a deal in March 2019.In the case of a no-deal Brexit, recognised UK breed societies and breeding operations will no longer be automatically entitled to enter animals into breeding books in the EU or extend breeding programmes onto the continent.The Department for the Environment said that such operations would have to apply to the European Commission for certification that they meet EU rules.However, EU-recognised breed societies and operations will continue to have access to the UK in the same way as they do now.Rail transport and rail safety standardsCross-Channel rail passengers have been warned they will be responsible for ensuring their tickets are sufficient to cover possible disruption in the event of a no-deal Brexit.This means some Eurostar and Eurotunnel customers may be tempted to buy more expensive amendable fares rather than cheaper fixed tickets.The document also explains that the UK is seeking bilateral arrangements with France, Belgium, the Netherlands&nbspand&nbspIreland to facilitate the continued smooth functioning of cross-border rail services.UK breeders of pedigree cattle will not be recognised by the EU in the event of a no-deal Brexit (Image:  IMAGES)Trading gas and electricity with the EUOperators of electrical power links with Europe will need to set up alternative trading arrangements in a no-deal Brexit.Around six percent of the UK&rsquos electricity is imported through power links with France, the Netherlands and Ireland and plans are in the pipeline to build several more.The Government and energy regulator Ofgem are working with interconnector operators to ensure new access rules are approved in Great Britain and are providing support to interconnectors engaging with EU Member State authorities.A separate paper said gas trading between Britain and Europe was not expected to change significantly in the event of a no-deal Brexit.Sanctions policyThe UK would look to carry over all sanctions imposed by the EU at the time of exit, according to the documents.New sanctions and anti-money laundering laws should be in place by March 2019 but any sanctions regimes that have not been addressed would continue as powers retained under the EU (Withdrawal) Act 2018.This means there will be no gaps in implementing existing sanctions regimes, the documents state.Regulating pesticidesThe EU is currently responsible for regulating the manufacture of pesticides.If Britain leaves without a deal, the Government says it will establish its own independent regulations and repatriate decision making on the products from the EU to the UK.The UK imports around six percent of its electricity from EU countries (Image:  IMAGES)Consumer rightsEU regulations currently govern consumer protection and allow people to buy products and services from anywhere in the bloc with the knowledge that the protections and safety standards are the same or similar in every member state.But the Government warns a no-deal Brexit may cause &ldquoan impact on the extent to which UK consumers are protected when buying goods and services in the remaining member states.UK consumers will also no longer be able to use the UK courts effectively to seek redress from EU based traders.Structuring your businessUK firms that own or run business operations in EU states could face burdensome restrictions after a no-deal.The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said firms were likely to face changes to the law for example, this could involve meeting additional requirements in order to acquire real estate andor requiring additional approvals to operate.Restrictions may be more burdensome for branches or representative offices, as opposed to subsidiaries which have their own legal identity and are incorporated in the EU member state concerned.The guidance also warned UK citizens may face restrictions on their ability to own, manage or direct a company registered in the EU, potentially needing to meet additional requirements on nationality or residency.Geo-blocking of online contentGeo-blocking is the process of blocking access to a website on the basis of an internet user&rsquos EU nationality or place of residence within the EU.New EU rules prohibiting Geo-blocking are due to kick in on December 3.The regulation will also ban traders discriminating against customers on the basis of their nationality or place of residence when they are purchasing goods or services.A no-deal Brexit would mean the UK version of the Geo-blocking Regulation will cease to have effect in UK law.Eurostar passengers could face disruption in the event of a no deal (Image:  IMAGES)The other technical notices cover:Exporting GM food and animal feed productsExporting objects of cultural interestTrading and moving endangered species protected by CITESMaintaining the continuity of waste shipmentsExisting free trade agreementsImporting high-risk food and animal feedControl on mercuryControl on persistent organic pollutantsRegulating biocidal productsClassifying, labelling and packaging chemicalsHealth marks on meat, fish and dairy productsExport and import of hazardous chemicalsAccounting and auditProviding services including those of a qualified professionalGeo-blocking of online contentTaking horses abroad

title: brexit news theresa may brexit deal irish backstop eu news
story: THERESA May stands by her June proposals (Image: Jack TaylorGetty Images)A Downing Street spokesman today made it clear that the Prime Minister will not agree to staying in the EU&rsquos customs union for a period without a time limit.The proposal had been mooted as a solution to the so-called Northern Ireland backstop to resolve the problem around the land border with Ireland.But after Mrs May failed to persuade senior members of her cabinet on the solution while others including Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab have made it clear they would resign, Mrs May has ditched the suggestion.There are also serious questions whether Mrs May could get the proposal through parliament with the powerful European Research Group of Tory Brexiteer MPs set to vote against anything that stops Britain from &nbspagreeing its own free trade deals.                Brexiteer Bridgen predicts May could be ousted NEXT WEEK                Brexit news: Secret plans could see UK remain EU rule-taker after 2020While Britain remains in a customs union with the EU, Brussels gets to dictate trade policy and force new regulations on the UK.But a Downing Street spokeswoman told a Westminster media briefing: The Prime Minister would never agree to a deal which would trap the UK in a backstop permanently.The spokeswoman said Mrs May stood by her June proposals, adding: Our position is that this future economic relationship needs to be in place by the end of December 2021 at the latest.Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson (Image: LEON NEALAFPGetty Images)Leading Conservative Brexiteer Steve Baker responded that any backstop which went beyond a simple free trade agreement amounted to effectively committing the UK to membership of the single market and customs union.Mr Baker said: That won't wash. The British people voted to take back control over money, laws borders and trade.It is understood that a number of ministers voiced concern at a meeting with the PM in Downing Street on Thursday that any such backstop could leave the UK in an open-ended customs union, preventing it from seeking trade deals elsewhere in the world.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson has said it risks making the UK a permanent EU colony.Meanwhile, Chancellor Philip Hammond became the first senior Government figure to suggest that the backstop - designed to keep the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic open in the case that no broader EUUK trade deal is finalised - will probably have to come into effect for a period.But the Democratic Unionist Party, which props up Mrs May's minority Conservative administration in the House of Commons, urged her to resist any initiatives from Brussels which might threaten the Union.DUP Brexit spokesman Sammy Wilson said there would be consequences for Mrs May if she walked away from her promise to protect the Union.We are simply reminding her, you are being torn at the moment between what we believe are your gut instincts and your sound principles on the Union and at the same time the bullying, threatening behaviour of the EU, said Mr Wilson at a meeting of DUP MPs and Assembly members in Portadown.Go with your principles, go with your instinct, go with your responsibility to the people of the UK and show the EU negotiators the door.BREXIT negotiations: Theresa May and European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker (Image: EMMANUEL DUNANDAFPGetty Images)Mrs May chaired a meeting of the inner Cabinet on Brexit progress Mrs May set out in June proposals for a temporary customs arrangement to ensure that the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic remains open in the case that no broader EUUK trade agreement has been finalised.The document stated that the UK Government expects this arrangement to remain in place no later than the end of December 2021.But the EU is mounting resistance to any specific time limit being included in the text of the UK's Withdrawal Agreement, while Leave-backing ministers are understood to be insistent that the end of the arrangement should be more precisely defined than the vague term temporary.Earlier, Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, who was not at the Downing Street meeting, pointedly refused to endorse the Prime Minister's Chequers blueprint for Brexit.International Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt and the Leader of the Commons Andrea Leadsom - who, like Ms McVey, both backed Leave in the referendum in 2016 - were also said to harbour deep concerns.A number of ministers, including Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, Environment Secretary Michael Gove and International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, were said to have raised concerns over the backstop issue during the 90-minute meeting.&nbsp

story: Many participations in classics like Grand National come from Ireland and France (Image: Harry TrumpGetty Images)The Government has published its latest round of no deal contingency papers which included moving horses, energy supply in Northern Ireland, EU regulations for businesses and continuing sanctions regimes against rogue states.Concerns had been raised about horse racing and participation in classics like the Derby and the Grand National because many participants come from Ireland and France.But the guidance issued by Whitehall made it clear that British races will not be affected because there will be no bar on horses entering the UK.                'Never agree!' May to REFUSE Brexit deal trapping UK under EU ruleHowever, EU races like the Arc de Triomphe in Paris may be more difficult for British based horses.The document said: We are seeking discussions with the European Commission to allow the UK to become a listed third country on the day we leave the EU.However, to allow effective contingency planning, in the event that the UK is not a listed country equine movement to the EU could not take place.We are confident, however, that the UK meets the animal health requirements to secure listing, as other countries such as Australia and New Zealand have done.Meanwhile, there was a warning that UK firms that own or run business operations in EU states could face burdensome restrictions after a no-deal Brexit, Government guidance warned.The Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy said firms were likely to face changes to the law for example, this could involve meeting additional requirements in order to acquire real estate andor requiring additional approvals to operate.The papers also made it clear that the UK would look to carry over all EU agreed sanctions at the time of exit.New sanctions and anti-money laundering laws should be in place by March 2019 but any sanctions regimes that have not been addressed would continue as powers retained under the EU (Withdrawal) Act 2018.This means there will be no gaps in implementing existing sanctions regimes, the documents state.Fears over British based horses to compete Europe  (Image: JACQUES DEMARTHONAFPGetty Images)However, the status of future EU employees in the UK and British ones in the EU could come under question because there will no system for mutual recognition by the UK and EU of the qualifications of professionals like doctors, pharmacists or architects if there is no deal.Nevertheless, the Department for Business said that any professionals whose EEA (European Economic Area) qualifications have been recognised in the UK before Brexit day will not be affected while the European Commission has said the same about UK qualifications recognised in EU states.Finally, claims that Northern Ireland faces the threat of electricity blackouts if the UK leaves out of the EU without a deal have been dismissed.The Government has pointed out that the single Irish energy market is not dependent on the EU and was set up separately to it.If there is no deal the papers said the Government will help residents and businesses prepare for the possibility of no deal said there was a risk that the single electricity market may not be able to continue.

story: The political activist and former speechwriter for Iain Duncan Smith launched the blistering attack on the Prime Minister Theresa May during a segment for BBC political programme &lsquoThis Week&rsquo.Mr Montgomerie claimed that Mrs May had allowed Brexit to define her Premiership and had offered up few new policy ideas.He also strongly criticised her much beleaguered Chequers proposals, adding that if Conservative ministers wanted to &lsquochuck Chequers&rsquo then they would have to &lsquochuck&rsquo the Prime Minister too.Mr Montgomerie said: &ldquoMrs May&rsquos tunnel vision has led her to stick to one lane - Brexit - to define her Premiership. May to REFUSE Brexit deal trapping UK under EU rule&ldquoIf like Jeremy Corbyn, she&rsquod moved beyond the European Union, she might have had a pack of policies for MPs to unite around.He continued: &ldquoAs it stands if the Conservative Party wants to chuck Chequers, it has to chuck Theresa May&rsquos premiership into the gutter along with it.&ldquoWhen it comes to political judgement, the Prime Minister is ln her third and final strike.&ldquoAt the general election, she managed to throw away a 20 percent opinion poll lead, leaving the government at the mercy of the DUP.Brexit news: Tim Montgomerie called for the Prime Minister to step down  (Image: BBC &bull Getty)&ldquoA year later, she presented Britain with her Chequers plan, and that had landed with an almighty thud.&ldquoWhy would we trust her with the final negotiations of Brexit? The most important moment in our post-war history.&ldquoShe needs to go - and now!This is not the first time Mr Montgomerie has launched an acid-tounged attack on Mrs May.                Brexiteer MP's PERFECT comeback when branded 'bug-eyed eurosceptic'                Brexit news: No-deal could loss of more than 70 free trade dealsIn September, Mr Montogomerie wrote a sensational article in the Sunday  claiming that Mrs May has caused her Cabinet members to war with each other.He said: &ldquoTory MPs should have ended her leadership of the Conservative Party in the immediate aftermath of the election disaster.&ldquoShe hasn&rsquot survived because her parliamentary colleagues believe her promise to lift them out of the mess she confessed to landing them in.&ldquoShe&rsquos survived because they&rsquore scared of a messy leadership contest and worried that the new leader may be worse than the nurse they desperately still cling to.He added: &ldquoBut, at some point, they&rsquoll have to summon up the courage to oust Mrs May.&ldquoThey&rsquore kidding themselves if they think she&rsquoll make it easy. I know via an indiscretion from one of her closest allies that she dearly wants to continue as PM eve once a Brexit deal is completed (or fudged).This afternoon May&rsquos Government has released a further set of Brexit contingency plans outlining the potential impacts of a no deal split and how ministers are preparing for them.The 29 &lsquotechnical notices&rsquo drawn up by Whitehall cover areas including free trade agreements after the split, fishing policy and rail transport.The UK will lose free trade agreements with more than 70 non-EU countries around the world if it leaves without a deal, the Government warned.Theresa May could also face a backlash over her Brexit plans if her Cabinet rebels over her backstop plan, which they fear will lock Britain into a customs union with Brussels with no time limit &ndash meaning the UK could remain in the EU indefinitely.The plan, which was discussed by Mrs May&rsquos &ldquowar cabinet of senior ministers yesterday, is believed not to include an end date &ndash something which will enrage hardline Brexiteers including Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg.The proposals are set to be presented to EU leaders in Brussels next week.However, ministers including International Trade Secretary Liam Fox have voiced their disapproval already.Speculation is rife that there could be more resignations to add to those of Mr Johnson as Foreign Secretary, as well as Brexit Secretary David Davis, in the wake of the unveiling of Mrs May&rsquos Chequers blueprint earlier this year.

title: Bavaria election 2018 polls Angela Merkel Germany election results CSU
story: Speaking to Deutsche Welle News, journalist Bettina Vestring claimed German Chancellor Angela Merkel will be blamed for the dramatic impact the Bavaria election will have on Berlin on Sunday.&nbspThe Christian Social Union (CSU), which is Ms Merkel&rsquos coalition partner and Bavarian sister party to the CDU, will be contesting the vote on October 14.&nbspMs Vestring claimed the CSU will suffer badly at the Sunday's regional election causing Angela Merkel's allies to put the blame entirely on the German Chancellor.She said:&nbsp&ldquoUltimately I think perhaps not even that much will change in Bavaria.                Bavaria election 2018 polls: What time do polling stations open?&ldquoI think in some ways the effects will be more dramatic in Berlin because the ruling coalition of Angela Merkel in Berlin, the parties it consists of are set to suffer in Bavaria and suffer badly.&ldquoThat&rsquos true not just for the CSU but also for the Social Democrats.&ldquoAngela Merkel herself will carry some of the blame for the Bavarian results.&ldquoAnd her coalition partners will make sure she will take the maximum of it and unrest within her own party is growing.The Berlin expert claimed the Bavarian vote on Sunday will be a &ldquovictory for democracy.Bavaria election: Angela Merkel's ally will 'suffer badly' at the Bavaria election, claims expert (Image: &bullDW)She added: &ldquoI stand by that. I think it will be a victory for democracy on two parts.&ldquoFirst of all, I think it&rsquos absurd for democracy to be ruled by the same party for 60 years.&ldquoIn that sense, moving closer towards a change of Government in Bavaria is good for democracy and it&rsquos also good for the state because parties that are too long in power get too crusty.&ldquoBut secondly, perhaps even more important in this time and this political climate that we have now, I think the CSU in Bavaria is getting punished for being too populist.Voters will take to the polls on Sunday to elect the 180 members of the 18th Landtag of Bavaria.The regional elections could weaken the national government if the CSU is not successful and blame is placed on Horst Seehofer, who is Ms Merkel&rsquos Interior Minister and leader of the CSU.A poll published by German broadcaster ARD last week showed support for the CSU had fallen to 33 percent, despite usually getting around 50 percent of the vote.The poll showed the Greens Party in second place, with 18 percent voter support.This was ahead of the Social Democrats, who were at 11 percent, with the far-right AfD slightly behind with 10 percent.As a result, this could be the CSU&rsquos worst performance since 1950, when it received 27.4 percent of the vote.Bavaria is the largest state, and one of the richest, in Germany, so the results will make a big difference.

title: emmanuel macron news cabinet reshuffle france poll
story: The president&rsquos satisfaction rating has sunk to around 30 per cent in recent months (Image: JOEL SAGETAFPGetty Images)A string of high-profile resignations have dented the young centrist&rsquos authority, and called into question his increasingly scrutinised top-down, monarchical style of leadership.The Elys&eacutee Palace said the reshuffle, which was expected on Wednesday, would not happen until after the 40-year-old centrist returns from a visit to Armenia late on Friday.The poll, conducted by Odoxa-Dentsu Consulting for France Info radio and Le Figaro daily, showed 53 percent of people polled believe the rejig is a &ldquoserious issue which shows the government is &ldquounable to attract new talent.The dragged-out reshuffle also shows there are &ldquodisagreements between Mr Macron and his Prime Minister Edouard Philippe, the respondents added.                Macron in crisis: French President cabinet reshuffle                &lsquoGET A GRIP&rsquo rival warns Macron as he must not KILL FranceHowever, 45 percent of those polled downplayed any sense of crisis inside the administration, saying the delay was a sign that Mr Macron &ldquoneeds time to choose good ministers and make sure they are up to the job.&nbspThe poll also showed that the French trust their prime minister more than their president: 55 percent said they trusted Mr Philippe, while only 29 percent said they trusted Mr Macron.49 percent of those interviewed said Mr Philippe was a more &ldquocompetent leader than his boss, who was described as competent by just 36 percent.The young centrist is however perceived as the &ldquomost authoritative member of government by 59 percent of the French and the &ldquomost charismatic by 50 percent.Mr Macron and Mr Philippe have been mulling over the reshuffle for a week following the departure of three ministers since late August, including interior minister and early Macron supporter G&eacuterard Collomb.The resignations have challenged the president&rsquos authority and stalled his reform plans, while the delayed overhaul has raised new questions about his ability to keep his team of ministers on track.&ldquoThe president wishes to take all the time necessary to draw up a team in a calm and professional way, the Elys&eacutee Palace said in a statement on Wednesday.Nearly half of those interviewed described Edouard Philippe as more competent than Macron (Image: LUDOVIC MARINAFPGetty Images)Macron ally and government spokesman Benjamin Griveaux, for his part, denied the administration was on the brink of collapse.He said: &ldquoThere is no ision in the government or the parliamentary majority on the political line we are pursuing.But Mr Macron&rsquos political rivals are observing the turmoil with glee, branding the reshuffle a &ldquofarce that has exposed a glaring lack of political experience in the ruling La R&eacutepublique en Marche party.The president&rsquos satisfaction rating has sunk to around 30 per cent in recent months as the French have grown increasingly frustrated by his arrogant behaviour and pro-business policies that are seen as favouring the rich over the poor.The Odoxa-Dentsu Consulting poll of 1,013 people aged 18 and over was carried out online between October 10 and October 11.

title: emmanuel macron news brigitte macron latest france president polls
story: Emmanuel Macron and his wife Brigitte (Image: ChesnotGetty Images)The president and his wife have brushed off criticism over their 24-year age gap and often gush over each other during interviews. They met when he was 15 and she was his teacher.&nbsp&ldquoNow, unfortunately, we are alone. That&rsquos what living in the Elys&eacutee Palace does to you: we can&rsquot trust anyone but each other. We&rsquore lonely together, but lonely nevertheless.&ldquoI trust Emmanuel and Emmanuel trusts me. That&rsquos all that matters, Mrs Macron was quoted as saying in the unauthorised biography of Mich&egravele &lsquoMimi&rsquo Marchand, the head of Bestimage, one of France&rsquos most powerful paparazzi photo agencies.                Brigitte Macron shows off slim legs in fitted blue dress                Macron under fire: Cabinet reshuffle delay is sign of SPLITMrs Marchand, 71, known to the French press as the &ldquoqueen of the paparazzi, is a close confidante of the presidential couple. She is also said to be organising public relations behind the scenes for the Macrons.The first lady and Mrs Marchand meet &ldquoevery Thursday morning to discuss the Macrons&rsquo public relations strategy, according to the French daily Le Parisien.The 24-year age gap between the president and his wife has long been a source of fascination for the French: the 40-year-old leader first met his now-wife when he was 15 and she was his married teacher.Mrs Marchand, for her part, has been credited for successfully spinning the eyebrow-raising affair into an inspiring love story ahead of the 2017 presidential campaign.Her photo agency was behind a series of staged, loved-up snaps of the Macrons which were splashed across the front covers of several glossy magazines such as the popular weekly Paris Match in the run up to the election, helping sway public opinion in favour of the then centrist candidate.Mr Macron&rsquos quick and improbable ascent to power &ndash he won the presidency with more than 60 percent of the vote &ndash demolished France&rsquos traditional mainstream parties, leaving both the left and the right in shambles.But as the shine has worn off his young presidency, and the impact of highly contested reforms to the country&rsquos rigid labour code and tax rules have yet to filter through, political rivals have sought to depict him as an increasingly isolated, aloof figure with little star power and appeal.&nbspParticularly harmful to Mr Macron in recent months were the resignations of three top ministers, including interior minister G&eacuterard Collomb, an early convert to so-called &lsquoMacronism&rsquo.Macron won the presidency with more than 60 percent of the vote last year (Image: FABRICE COFFRINIAFPGetty Images)Shortly before his resignation Mr Collomb said his team &ldquolacked humility and warned against hubris, an opinion shared by the French and reflected in polls. Mr Macron&rsquos popularity rating is currently hovering around 30 per cent.&ldquoThe issue here is not the government but the president, a president who is seen by French people as someone who doesn&rsquot listen to them, and even belittles them, said Jean-Daniel Levy of pollster Harris Interactive when asked to comment on the president&rsquos tepid ratings.But while Mr Macron doesn&rsquot face re-election until spring 2022, next May&rsquos European Parliament election and municipal voting in France in 2020 could quickly turn into a referendum on his performance and undermine his authority.

title: Italy news Matteo Salvini European Union Fornero law Italy budget plan
story: Speaking on Rai 3's Agor&agrave on Thursday, Italy's Deputy Prime Minister sent a stern message to Brussels as he pledged to go ahead with the budget plan already refused by the European Union.The die-hard eurosceptic told eurocrats to get a grip as he confirmed a key austerity law&nbsp - Fornero - introduced during the&nbspMario Monti technocratic government will be scrapped as part of the populist government's economic plan.&nbspMr Salvini said: &ldquoFor years I have repeated that once in Government I would have changed the Fornero law.&ldquoIf you think that now, just because someone in Brussels or Bank of Italy says &lsquono, you can&rsquot touch the Fornero law&rsquo, I say &lsquosure, I was joking&rsquo.                Doomed EU? Varoufakis says Italy pushing bloc close to disintegration                'Do the OPPOSITE' Salvini pledges to overturn EU's 'IMPOSED' policies&ldquo&lsquoI teased millions of Italian people, I won&rsquot change the Fornero law otherwise someone will be offended&rsquo?&ldquoNo. I&rsquom going ahead with it. Get a grip.The Fornero law, a piece of 2011 legislation, named after then-welfare minister Elsa Fornero, has become one of the primary symbols of EU-imposed austerity in Italy.The aim of the law was to raise cash and reassure markets of the commitment to spending discipline in the&nbspeurozone&rsquos&nbspthird-largest economy.Italy news: Matteo Salvini tells Brussels to 'get a grip'  (Image: RAI3&bull)Italian workers would be moved across to a defined contribution scheme, stopping indexing pensions above a certain income level for inflation and increasing the retirement age to 67.The Fornero reform was the main element of the &lsquoSave Italy&rsquo reform package.After the financial crisis of 2008 and the subsequent Sovereign debt crisis of 2010, Italy was ordered to slash public spending.However, the drastic cuts were viewed as another EU policy that punished ordinary people for the failings of governments,&nbsppolicymakers, and major US and European banks.Italians argued that the new generations were being forced to pay for the mistakes of their predecessors with the cuts implemented with the reform described by Italics Magazine as, &ldquomassive and, &ldquodisproportionally hitting the lower classes.Rome will submit its draft budget proposals to Brussels in mid-October, which will be followed by officials scrutinising the proposals to see if they follow EU-wide rules.Brussels may choose to launch a last-ditch attempt to reach a compromise with Rome over the differences before opting to reject it outright.If the Italian Government decides to refuse the Commission&rsquos proposed changes, officials would then seek to open an excessive deficit procedure against Rome.EU member states would have to give the action, which would designate a new fiscal path for Italy to balance its books, the go-ahead.

title: brexit news michel barnier canary islands irish border eu uk latest
story: The EU negotiator outlined his plan to &ldquode-dramatise the Northern Ireland issue (Image:  )Mr Barnier suggested a proposal similar to arrangements between Spain and the Canary Islands, which involves a control of the goods between the British province and the rest of the country.The EU negotiator outlined in a speech on Wednesday at a meeting of European businessmen in the European Parliament his plan to &ldquode-dramatise the Northern Ireland issue and argued checks could happen, for the most part, away from the border.He said: &ldquoFor customs and VAT checks, we propose using the existing customs transit procedures, companies in the rest of the UK would fill in their customs declarations online and in advance when shipping goods to Northern Ireland.&ldquoRegulatory checks, on industrial goods could be carried out by market surveillance authorities in the market or at the premises of companies in Northern Ireland.                BREXIT WARNING: Portillo says May faces 'MASSACRE' of support                 UK will NOT accept Brexit deal TRAPPING Britain in EU customs unionBut he insists there must still be some alignment between the North and South of Ireland.There would also need to be border controls between the EU and the rest of the UK to meet regulatory standards.The reformulated approach will mean light regulatory checks on the Irish Sea, no internal border in Ireland and full border controls on the Channel.Mr Barnier added: &ldquoThe UK wants to and will leave the single market and the customs union.But he insists there must still be some alignment between the North and South of Ireland (Image: )                No deal Brexit: British horse racing to continue contingency plan                'Theresa May needs to go NOW' Brexiteer demands she resign IMMEDIATELY&ldquoThis means that there must be checks on goods travelling between the EU and the UK &ndash checks that do not exist today. Customs and VAT checks, and compliance checks with our standards to protect our consumers, our economic traders and your businesses.&ldquoWe have agreed with the UK that these checks cannot be performed at the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.&ldquoA crucial question is, therefore, where they will take place. The EU is committed to respecting the territorial integrity and constitutional order of the UK, just like the UK has committed to respecting the integrity of our Single Market, including Ireland, obviously.&ldquoTherefore, the EU proposes to carry out these checks in the least intrusive way possible.There would also need to be border controls between the EU and the rest of the UK to meet standards (Image: )These arrangements exist for many EU member states, in particular the canaries.The news was met with optimism as the markets welcomed the statements, but there is still concern about the formula to be applied to the Irish border.This means there is still uncertainty over the real options of reaching an agreement before the European Council meeting on October 18.Additional reporting by Maria Ortega.

title: jean claude juncker everything wrong with eu
story: He is everything that’s wrong with the European project — and why it’s so vital that we leave.In his latest rant, he demanded “respect” and delivered a warning that “Press freedom has its limits”. Why Alas, Luxembourg’s finest is annoyed that the media keep reporting on the persistent rumours that he is half-cut most of the time.He must be to think, as he does, that the UK would have voted Remainonly HE had been involved in the referendum. Fat chance. He’d have doubled the Leave vote.The trials and tribulations of Brexit might have made some wonderit’s all worth the hassle. So it’s good of Jean-Claude, a puffed-up political pygmy, to remind us why we’re better off out.Brexiteers need to keep their eyes on the prize. Attention-seeking bores like Andrew Adonis and Alastair Campbell, plus shadowy campaign outfits, are trying their hardest to undermine Brexit.Nobody should think this battle is won. Nobody should be complacent about political battles still to come.And nobody who believes in a prosperous, independent nation should allow the perfect to be the enemy of the good when it comes to Britain’s departure, and walk into the Remainers’ “people’s vote” trap.We leave in less than six months. And when we do, we’ll raise a glass. Maybe Jean-Claude will join us.THE Universal Credit system IS a good idea – but the roll-out must be done properly.The Tories’ benefit changes in the last Government, making it more rewarding to be in work, are a big part of the ­reason employment is at a record high. UC is the final part of that puzzle.But reports that some working families could lose signicant amounts of cash overnight are deeply worrying.Our benefits regime needs to be firm.But it must also be fair.BOB Geldof warns Britain will be a ­“cultural jail” after Brexit.Quite why the power to strike our own trade deals will affect our ability to play guitar isn’t yet clear.In fact, when it comes to music, it’s Britain’s institutions that are more­ ­dangerous. The BBC has decided in its infinite wisdom to publish its entire archive of classical music to compete with streaming services and record labels. Why  Just because it can It’s a decision that sums up the big-state, God-complex thinking that seeps right through the BBC.Lord Hall promised to change Auntie’s tune – but he’s still hitting the wrong notesOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: house prices mortgages young people
story: All they are trying to do is the right thing. But this is the reality of trying to save up for a house.They work hard each month. They’d love to put something aside to save up for a home.But to live where there are good jobs, they have to spend so much on high rents that there’s nothing left over.So they can never save enough to break out of the cycle. No wonder they are frustrated.New figures show how bad things have got. The Institute for Fiscal Studies says four out of ten people in the  to -year-old age bracket couldn’t afford the mortgage on even the cheapest house in their area, eventhey had a deposit.The gap between prices and normal people’s earnings is just too big, because since  house prices in Britain have gone up more than in any other developed country.Expensive housing has meant that the proportion of young people on middle incomes who own their own home has collapsed: down from nearly two thirds  years ago, to just over a quarter today.We have to turn this round and restore home ownership.Many people feel they can’t get on and start a family until they have a nest of their own. Their lives are on hold.Politically it’s vital too. If young people don’t feel they’ve got a chance to get on in le, they are more likely to gamble and vote for extreme, disastrous politicians like Jeremy Corbyn.Even younger people who are earning decent wages feel squeezed, because they face a combination of high house prices and chunky repayments on their student loans.The Prime Minister is acutely aware of this. That’s why she’s set up a review of student fees, and moved to make housing her Number  priority other than Brexit.Hence her announcement of massive funding to build more affordable housing for people on lower incomes. But there’s much more to do.Building more homes for people to buy is a big part of the answer. Since  we have built only half as many houses as France each year, and so house prices have gone up twice as fast.Some people say building more means we must tear up the planning system and concrete over the countryside.But we know that approach won’t work. When Gordon Brown was PM we tried setting each area massive housing targets. All those targets built was resentment. We need a smarter approach to tackle the reasons people often oppose new housing.We build in the wrong places. Instead of tacking on new estates to existing towns and villages without enough new school places or parking places, let’s get back into the business of building planned new cities and towns.Let’s build upwards in our city centres with taller buildings, rather than just sprawling cities outwards.What drives people mad is seeing developers make massive windfall profits when they get planning permission, but then not sharing those benefits with local residents.Imagine instead,new houses being built next door always paid for people in neighbouring streets to get cheap homes for their children to buy. People would feel much better about development.Restoring the dream of home ownership isn’t just about building more houses though.We need to think about the balance of rented properties and home ownership. Over the last ten years we’ve built many new homes each year, but the number of homeowners fell. How come The reason is that the number of properties being snapped up by buy-to-let landlords has grown faster than we have built new ones.Don’t get me wrong. Landlords, who have themselves worked hard, weren’t doing anything wrong.Butwe want to get home ownership growing again we need to encourage savers to put their money into shares and into growing businesses rather than just bidding up the price of houses. The think tank Onward proposed this week that we should offer a tax break to landlords who sell their homes to their tenants.This “Chance to Buy” would be a bit like the Right to Buy Margaret Thatcher introduced for council tenants. It could be paid for by tax changes which would discourage people from buying up new buy-to-let properties.So fewer landlords, more homeowners.Young people just want the same chances previous generations enjoyed. So let’s build more by building smarter, and give a new generation the chance to buy a home.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gutless knight sir craig mackey
story: I thought: “Nah, that can’t be true. ­Someone who hates coppers has made that up.” But it WAS true, all true. And I still can’t believe it.In March last year, a jihadi went on a rampage in Westminster.Then he smashed into the perimeter fence and entered New Palace Yard, a few dozen feet away from where our politicians were gathered.Armed with a kne, he attacked anyone he saw. He murdered PC Keith Palmer.And now the thing that beggars belief. At that very moment, the acting commissioner of the politan Police, Craig Mackey, was leaving the scene in a car. He was inches away from Masood.He was only a few feet away when the Islamic terrorist was busy stabbing his colleague, PC Palmer.He watched the stabbing take place. And what did he do  He drove off, sharpish, having locked the windows of his car.He told an inquest into the murder: “I was in shirt-sleeves with no radio. title: storm callum uk weather latest forecast gales

title: m26 motorway closed brexit lorry park
story: Ministers last night snuck out plans to shut down the M in Kent so builders can work on the road.It will be redeveloped to enable it to hold lorries on part or all of the roada No Deal Brexit leads to huge queues at the port of Dover.MPs responded with fury to the news which was slipped out without any explanation.The M, which connects the M around London to the M running towards Dover, was closed at pm last night and reopened at .am.The closures will continue until Monday - and will then restart in the run-up to Christmas.It will be shut down every night from November  to December  as building work continues.Ministers are worried thatwe leave the EU without an agreement, there will be gridlock around Dover as lorry drivers face reams of new red tape.They have developed contingency plans to park goods vehicles along the side of the M - as well as taking over the M.A spokesman for Highways England said: “As part of wider resilience planning, Highways England has been asked by the Department for Transport to develop plans to utilise the M to hold heavy goods vehicles, should further capacity be required in the future.“We will be undertaking site surveys on the M during October leading to the installation of two gates in the central reservation to support the safe management of freight in the future,needed.”Local MP Tom Tugendhat blasted transport chiefs for failing to provide advance notice of the works.Speaking in the Commons, he said: I was assured the works were not planned and only yesterday was it confirmed to me that Highways England had said that is exactly what was planned, despite having told me the reverse a week earlier.Transport Secretary Chris Grayling responded by claiming the M wouldnt be needed as a lorry parkBritain successfully strikes a deal with the EU.He said: I do not expect any of the contingencies that we have in place for a No Deal Brexit to be needed because Im confident we will reach a sensible agreement.

title: kier builders leave home covered in concrete dust botched job
story: Ex-soldier Stephen Wiseman and pregnant we Abbie were confronted with dust in every corner of their home – including in the nursery, upstairs in their bed and even inside the oven.The house was also covered in dusty footprints – even trekking into the couple’s bedroom where no repairs needed to be done.The couple have since described the service of construction company Kier as “diabolical”, saying the two day repair job had stretched into weeks of heartache.Stephen said the couple had bought their Camborne, Cornwall home from the company in , noticing the lino in the kitchen, downstairs bathroom and hallway had started bubbling barely a year after moving in.But the expectant parents said it took months for the company to finally send someone to repair the issue – only with repeated calls from the couple warning the flooring needed to be done by the arrival of their baby.The repair job stretched to four days – with the couple ing home to find the two-storey property covered in dust in August.Stephen said: “Since buying the house from Kier in , their aftercare has been diabolical.“They just don’t want to do anything for us.”He said he couldn’t believe his eyes when he checked on the house on August , days after the job was supposed to be completed.Stephen, an ex-soldier, said: “I was gobsmacked – they have absolutely ruined our house.“The dust was in every single room.“You could see it covered everything – the walls, clothes, sofas, all of our clothes, and bedding.”He said urine covered their toilet, while the front doormat was snapped.Stephen said he had taped up the opening of cupboards in the kitchen, but the plates and bowls were still covered.He said he and nurse we Abbie, who had been put up at a nearby Premier Inn for the repair works, were told cleaners would come and restore the home.Kier did book cleaners to try to restore the home – but the two cleaners, armed with just vacuum cleaners, were unable to handle the mess.Instead, industrialist fire damage cleaners had to be booked.Meanwhile, the couple were told Kier could no longer help accommodate them – despite their pleas they had nowhere to go.The couple ended up staying at Stephen’s parents house, with pregnant Abbie sleeping on the couch as Stephen kipped on the floor.Eight-month-pregnant Abbie had to be taken to hospital after concerns for bleeding, with the couple believing it was brought on by stress.The couple have finally been able to move back into their house, since welcoming son Jack into the world.But they said Kier had refused to help them further – giving them only £, to cover the cost of replacing their child’s nursery, TVs, and DVD player.Stephen, who is asthmatic, said the couple still found dust in the home.He said: “They have given us money to help replace the things that need replacing, but there is still the time and effort to buy everything new again.“They don’t care now – they gave us money and think that’s it.“They’re absolutely delusional.”A Kier spokesperson said: “We aim to always to deliver the highest quality homes for our customers and unfortunately, the case of Mr and Mrs Wiseman is an unusual example of where we didn’t meet our own high standards. We would like to apologise again for the disruption caused. The works have been completed and we have paid compensation and all expenses.“We have investigated the actions of the sub-contractor involved and have already taken action to ensure this doesn’t happen again.To continually improve our customer experience, we’ve invested in a new customer care system and we will continue to review all aspects of our service.”
