title: brexit deal latest economy boost philip hammond
story: A surprisingly cheery Chancellor said there was a change of pace in negotiations in recent weeks, and there could be a double deal idendBritain reaches an agreement on the bloc in the coming weeks.Raising hopes that a deal was on the cards soon, the usually gloomy Mr Hammond said that there had been a really important step change in talks between the Uk and Brussels.He told the BBC this morning ahead of IMF meetings in Bali: If we are able to get a good deal for Britain as we leave the EU, I believe there will be a deal idend for us.The deal would lt the public finances by raising the growth of the economy, and would mean he could spend £billion hes had to set aside to prepare for a rocky Brexit.The extra money could be used to pave the way for the end of austerity next year, as Theresa May promised in her recent party conference speech.He said: So long as we get a good deal that protects the UK economy there will be two sources of upside...we are successful in negotiating that package there will be an upside idend in terms of the economy and fiscal numbers.The second bonus is that I’ve been holding slightly larger amounts of fiscal buffer than would otherwise be necessary because of the unusual degree of uncertainty that exists at the moment.If that uncertainty is unwound, logically one would need a little bit less of a fiscal buffer and some of that could be released to support the spending envelope or to deliver tax cuts or to pay down the debt more quickly. We have choices.But Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said his words smacked of good old fashioned spin.It comes after the Office for Budget Responsibility warned yesterday of the consequences of No Deal - saying it would harm the pound and the economy.He said the EU Commission had been very engaged over the last ten days, raising hopes further that a deal can be signed at a crunch summit coming up next week.But Mr Hammond also raised the prospect that the Brexit backstop - which is currently in a period of crunch negotiation - will probably be needed after we leave the EU.He said: Were very clear this has to be a temporary period, but it is true that there needs to be a period - probably following the transition period that weve negotiated and before we enter into our long-term partnership - just because of the time it will take to implement the systems required.He vowed that Britain would not going to remain in anything indefinitely.A deal would be welcome news for the Chancellor, who is under pressure to find extra money to pay for the extra cash for the NHS that Mrs May promised earlier this year.And hes also facing grumblings from backbench Tory MPs to reverse cuts to the welfare budget.Yesterday DWP Secretary Esther McVey said for the first time that some people would be worse off after Universal Credit was rolled out next year.The troubled new system has already been plagued with problems since Brits started to move onto it, and its years behind schedule.

title: poppi worthington no evidence dads laptop
story: Paul Worthington, , viewed porn on the computer hours before the -month-olds death at home in Barrow-in-Furness in December .But cops did not seize the laptop at the time — one of a series of blunders in the botched investigation which has led to no prosecutions over tragic Poppis death.An inquest in January - title: gay penguins sphen magic raise chick sydney aquarium
story: Sphen and Magic have become so inseparable they have been allowed to start a nest with each other in Sea Le, in Sydney, Australia.  The same-sex couple - collectively known as Sphengic - began forging an intense relationship with each other just before breeding season got underway. The Gento penguins could be seen waddling in tandem and swimming alongside and were so close it was decided to let them adopt. But before this they were given antenatal classes.This entailed the flightless birds being given a dummy egg to allow them to practice incubating and develop their parenting skills.And by all accounts they seem to be taking to the task like a penguin does to water. It appears that the pair are naturals, although older and more mature Sphen is more focused on incubating while Magic has taken on the task of warding off other birds from swiping their pebbles which they use for their nests.JUST like some humans, penguins form same sex relationships. The first mention of this was in  when explorer George Murray Levick spotted male birds coupling up at Cape Adare.Seemingly scandalised by the sight, the Edwardian scientist described the behaviour as depraved. More recently the behaviour has been observed in a number of zoos. In  Jumbs and Hurricane, two Humboldt penguins at Wingham Wildle Park in Kent became inseparable and became celebrities in their own right.They later successfully hatched and reared an egg given to them as surrogate parents after the mum abandoned it halfway through incubation.Last month a gay penguin couple “kidnapped” a baby last while its parents waddled off for a swim, according to a zookeeper claimed.Apparently the drama unfolded in a zoo in Denmark when the chick’s mum and dad were having their daily paddle.Animal keeper Sandie Hedegård Munck told Danish broadcaster DR the male penguin couple at Odense Zoo have been desperate to become parents.So, she claims when they saw the chick being “neglected” by its parents, they decided to intervene and snatch it in hope of adopting it.

title: christopher cooksey stephanie watkiss trial
story: Christopher Cooksey, , allegedly kept hold of girlfriend Stephanie Watkisss phone to keep her family away from her.Detective Inspector Laura Jones said that an examination of Stephanies phone showed she only had five contacts in it.Stephanie had told the DI that Cooksey would write the messages himself.She said: She said she was petried of him.A court heard Stephanie, , met lovely guy Cooksey at her gym before he became allegedly became controlling.Her sister, Samantha Smith, told the court she had suspicions that something wasnt right when she got a text from Stephanie saying that she would not be joining the family for Christmas.She told the court that when she confronted Ms Watkiss about the last minute change of plans, she was horried to find out that it was actually Cooksey who had been messaging her.She said in Cardf Crown Court: Stephanie said it was not her. She did not have a phone anymore. Chris was in control of her phone.Stephanie met Cooksey, ,  who is on trial for controlling and coercive behaviour at their local gym.Ms Smith told the jury that Cooksey initially seemed friendly, polite and charming, adding: All the things you want to hear your sister say about her boyfriend.She said: She told me she had met a lovely guy called Chris and that they were going on a date.She did speak very highly of him. She said he wasn’t Brad Pitt but he was nice to look at.He had allegedly flown into a rage at her office Christmas party and when they got back to their BB, he grabbed her by the neck and forced her to snort lines of cocaine.Prosecutor Matthew Cobbe said: He insisted that she clean herself up but also insisted she take cocaine.On another occasion, the court was told that the couple had argued about a Facebook message from .He then allegedly forced his girlfriend to drink Caribbean rum based drink Malibu.Mr Cobbe said: “He ed to the room with a bottle of Malibu, forcing her to drink a large amount.“She took herself half-dressed to the kitchen to drink the Malibu. She forced it down as he watched.”  Cooksey, of Pontypool, Gwent, denies one count of administering a poisonous or noxious substance to Stephanie in December last year.He also denies four counts of assault occasioning actual bodily harm, one of assault by beating, one of  imprisonment, and one of controlling and coercive behaviour.The trial continues.

title: family house torn down too tall stoke
story: Council inspectors said the massive property in Lightwood, Stoke-on-Trent breaches planning laws by looming over neighbours houses.But the Naseem family say they cannot afford to spend an extra £, lowering the roof.They initially got approval from Stoke City Council for a two-storey building to be put up in leafy Sandwell Place.But the addition of dormer windows in the eaves pushed the roof up an extra ft in above the approved height after builders failed to dig foundations that were deep enough.Councillors had deferred making a decision for six-months to seea compromise could be reached, Stoke On Trent Live reported.But members of the planning committee voted in favour of enforcing the planning permission — meaning the house could be torn down.Dad-of-five As Naseem now has one last chance to save his home with another planning application currently going through the approval process.His we, Faranzana As, told a recent council meeting: “It’s not fair. It’s worrying us. I don’t know what will happen now.”Some locals are backing the family in their fight to save the home.Neigbour Becky Bateman, who lives opposite, told the paper: I hope it doesn’t come to demolition.When they started building it, it ripped my house to pieces. It was horrendous the whole house shook.It shouldn’t be that big, but As says it’s because the groundworks aren’t deep enough.Another resident added: “They’ve gone over and above the planning regulations.But a majority of councillors on the planning committee remain committed to enforcing their decision.Cllr David Evans said: We should take action. I’m not happy with the deferral.Councillor Ross Irving said: We have been here for months and months on end and we need to send a message to sort this out.

title: netflix spotify abroad no deal brexit
story: EU laws which prohibit firms from blocking access to websites based on a customers nationality or place of residence wont applytheres No Deal, new government documents released today said.The European Unions digital single market rules - which came into place earlier this year - mean that users can go and use Netflix anywhere around the EU just as they are in the UK. The rules apply to services including Prime and Amazon Music too.But this wont be the casewe end up quitting the bloc without a deal in place. Its the latest in a string of warnings of what could happen in the event of a No Deal Brexit.Documents released said today: In a ‘no deal’ scenario, the UK version of the Geo-Blocking Regulation will cease to have effect in UK law.Netflix access ies from country to country - but within the EU they provide the same content as your home country for a certain period of time.Netflix that Brits would still have access to their accounts after we leave the EU - but programmes could y.A spokesperson told The Sun today: UK Netflix subscribers are able to access Netflix everywhere in the world Netflix is available and will continue to do so once the UK leaves the EU.Spoty say you can use your in a country dferent than the one registered on your account for up to  days. After that, you need to upgrade to Premium or change the country registered on your account.Dominic Raabs Brexit Department has put out more notices to try and help companies prepare for No Deal and how to protect themselves.Its all part of plans to try and get companies ready no matter what might happen - and prove to Brussels we can survive without signing a deal.Mr Raab said today: Securing a good deal with our EU partners remains our top priority.But,the EU doesnt match the ambition and pragmatism weve showed, we have the plans in place to avoid, mitigate or manage the risk of no deal - and make a success of Brexit.Todays fresh round of documents come after the Office for Budget Responsibility warned yesterday that No Deal could have a dire effect on the UK economy.Todays documents revealed:Today ministers revealed that deals the EU has with other countries wont apply to Britain in the event of No Deal.Notices said they would seek to bring into force bi-lateral UK-third country agreements from exit day, or as soon as possible whenever possible.And it would also be bad news for Brits using the Eurostar to travel between Britain and the EU.Official guidance says Brits should make sure they buy flexible tickets to make sure they are protected to cover possible disruption.Any trains could require new licences to operate on day one of a No Deal Brexit, it said.Brits who choose to buy package holiday deals from EU providers should mostly be coveredthe firm goes bust, but it might get more tricky, the documents also revealed.It will not protect consumers who purchase packages from EU based traders which are not targeting business activities in the UK.Sothey dont advertise in Britain, you may not be covered for compensationthe business goes bust.Brits have already been told to plan their holidays three months in advance - and millions should renew their passportthey are going abroad after next spring.And it it could be lights out in Northern Ireland under worse-case scenario plans -  because of an old agreement with the Republic of Ireland where they share an energy market.If there were no deal, the Republic could cut off power to the north completely.  Electricity markets have been told to set up alternative trading arrangements.Consumer groups warned that it could be a bonfire of rights next March too - because there may be an impact on the extent to which UK consumers are protected from buying faulty goods in other member states.Laws are similar, but they would not be allowed to use UK courts to solve disputes, and any UK court laws could be hard to enforce outside the bloc.Federation of Small Businesses Chairman Mike Cherry said the latest warnings proved we had reached a tipping point in negotiations and called on ministers to come together to make progress at next weeks crunch EU meeting.He said today: The time has now come for both the UK Government and the EU to show the necessary pragmatism to agree a good deal that allows businesses in the UK and the EU to thrive both now and in the future.But Labours Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer said not enough preparations had been done.He stormed: The Government’s no deal planning won’t reassure anyone. Ministers have barely scratched the surface of what would need to be done in the event of the UK crashing out of the EU without a deal.In the last set of notices it was revealed that British tourists could face more expensive holidayswe leave without a deal - because the  cost of using your card in Europe will increase.The papers also revealed the Government plans to slap VAT on deliveries from Europe, increasing the price of most goods by  per cent.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: two in three tenants on universal credit cant pay their rent on time landlords say
story: A shock new survey from property owners found that the number of tenants going into rent arrears had rocketed under the past year to  per cent, up from  per cent last year.It found that Universal Credit claimants owed an average of £, - which is almost a  per cent increase on last year.They complained that it took on average two months for officials to pay them their benefits directly - on top of the  months of rent that had already accrued.The study of , landlords for the Residential Landlords Association found that tenants owed them around four months of cash before they were paid the rent owed.And one in five of them said their mortgage provider wouldnt let them rent to people who were on benefits.The average amount owed by Universal Credit tenants in rent arrears has increased by % in comparison to the previous  months - from £,. in  to £,..Half of landlords with Universal Credit tenants had asked for an automatic payment for the benefits to be paid directly to them.Some reported that they didnt get paid by the DWP for up to a YEAR.Yes, in certain circumstances.If a tenant is renting a council house or private association, they have to pay the rent to their landlords themselves.But some can ask for the benefits to go straight to their landlord -they have  months rent arrears already orthey find it hard to budget due to personal circumstances.Landlords then have to go to the Department for Work and Pensions to ask for this, or the tenant can request it.Visit gov.uk for more details.RLA Policy Director, David Smith, said today that the system wasnt fit for purpose and needed urgent review.The group said that mechanisms needed to be put in place for them to reclaim rent when Universal Credit tenants leave a property owning them money.He said: “Our research shows clearly that further changes are urgently needed to Universal Credit.We welcome the constructive engagement we have had with the Government over these issues but more work is needed to give landlords the confidence they need to rent to those on Universal Credit.“We feel a major start would be to give tenants the right to choose to have payments paid directly to their landlord. This would empower tenants to decide what is best for them rather than being told by the Government.”The Governments flagship benefits system, Universal Credit, is being slowly rolled out across the country, but has been beset with problems already.Millions more are set to go onto it next year, and it will roll six benefits into one single payment.Brits have already had to wait months for their payments to begin, and some have been forced into food banks and risked losing their homes as a result.It was also claimed that the new system could fuel domestic violence too - because the payments for whole families are only paid into one bank account.

title: garden shed alley rent price
story: The cosy outbuilding in Sutton, Dublin was offered as a one-bed property with a fully equipped kitchen.The shocking advert was pulled down by Spotahome after furious househunters reported the listing.It appears to offer a plywood shack bolted to the outside of a larger house.A single mattress on a shelf can be reached by climbing a ladder - advertised as some stairs.The listing read: The flat has a fully-equipped kitchen when you walk in.It also has a sitting area, with table and chairs. You can get up to the bed by climbing some stairs. Below the bed is the bathroom, complete with toilet and shower.A Spotahome spokesperson said: Spotahome is an online residential rentals  that aims to demonstrate each property in a realistic manner through photos, detailed videos and floor plans.Our job is to very the property’s existence, features and location to facilitate rentals without in-person viewings.As a marketplace, it is the landlord’s responsibility to ensure they meet all legal requirements.Clearly this listing didn’t meet requirements as it only has a -ring hob and minimum standards require a -ring hob with oven and grill, and a cooker hood.We have taken the feedback from Twitter users on board, and have unpublished the property.In regards to the price, landlords set their own pricing, terms and conditions and the contract is signed directly between the tenant and the landlord.

title: ministers save 50 note
story: No new reddies have been issued since  and Whitehall bean counters wanted to phase them out - but now a new polymer note is to be unveiled.Concerns they were only used by criminals and currency investors sparked calls for the to million in circulation to be withdrawn.In March the Treasury said “the £ note is believed to be rarely used for routine purchases and is instead held as a store of value.And they added: “There is also a perception among some that £ notes are used for money laundering, hidden economy activity, and tax evasion.”But following a three month listening exercise, Treasury Minister Robert Jenrick has stepped into save the note and demand the Bank of England make the new ones in the UK.And the top Tory says it will have cutting edge security measures to deter criminal use.A competition will be held to design the note, reopening the hotly debated subject of which famous Brits to feature.Current £ notes feature Matthew Boulton and James Watt, pioneers of the industrial revolution.But the Bank of England were slammed for failing to feature more women when redesigning £, £ and £ notes.Mr Jenrick told The Sun: “Our coins and notes are respected and recognised the world over and are a key part of the UK’s heritage and identity.He added: “People should have as much choice as possible when it comes to their money and we’re making sure that cash is here to stay.And the Bank of England said: “We are committed to providing the public with high quality notes they can use with confidence. Moving the £ note onto polymer is an important next step to ensure that we can continue to do that.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: princess makos wedding fiance kei komouro marriage delayed japan
story: Heres what we know about the princess and the plans for her big day.Princess Mako of Akishino is the first child and elder daughter of Fumihito, Prince Akishino, and Kiko, Princess Akishino, and a member of the Japanese Imperial Family.She is the eldest grandchild of Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko at -years-old.The Princess graduated from  International Christian University in Mitaka, Tokyo in  with a Bachelors degree in Art and Cultural Heritage.She went on to study in the UK at the University of Leicester and at the University of Edinburgh.Princess Mako became the project researcher of the University of Tokyos museum on  April .The wedding of Japan’s Princess Mako will be postponed for two years because of insufficient preparations as the imperial palace denied speculation the decision was related to tabloid criticism of her fiance’s family background.Mako and her college classmate Kei Komuro, a commoner, announced their engagement last September and were to wed in November.In announcing the delay, the Imperial Household Agency cited “a series of important ceremonies next year,” apparently meaning the planned handover of the Chrysanthemum Throne. No new dates for the wedding or its preceding rituals were given.Mako is Emperor Akihito’s oldest grandchild. The -year-old emperor is to abdicate on  April, , with Crown Prince Naruhito taking the throne the next day.The surprise delay less than a month before a planned ceremony in March to formalize the couple’s engagement left many people puzzled.Agency official Takaharu Kachi told reporters the decision was not related to tabloid reports about disputes between Komuro’s mother and her former partner over money she borrowed to cover her son’s tuition and never repaid, Japanese media reported.Mako said in a statement released through the agency the delay was due to insufficient preparations.Princess Mako said classmate Kei Komuro had won her heart with his bright smiles and sincerity.The couple, both , met when the the princess sat behind him at a campus meeting five years ago at Tokyos International Christian University, where they graduated.The decision means the princess will have to give up her royal title when they tie the knot.Announcing her engagement, Mako said First I was attracted by his bright smiles like the sun.He is a sincere, strong-minded, hard worker, and he has a big heart.Having a family still goes beyond my imagination, but I hope to make one that is warm, comfortable and filled with smiles.The couple maintained a long-distance relationship as Mako studied in Britain and Komuro in the U.S. for one year.Mako introduced him to her parents, Prince Akishino, second in line to the Chrysanthemum throne, and Princess Kiko, as someone she wished to share her future with.Komuro said he was so thankful and happy to have been accepted by her parents, and her grandparents, Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko.

title: pompeii shrine vesuvius volcano discovered
story: The site - which has been buried in ash since the volcano exploded in AD - looks identical to how it would have in its Roman heyday.One stunning picture shows a painting of two coiled snakes - symbols of wealth and happiness.Romans believed the murals could ward evil from the house.Another shows a pair of dogs fighting a wild boar, while a peacock stands alone at ground level.Site director Massimo Osanna said: The peacock appeared to be walking in the garden of the courtyard. Its a game between illusion and reality. These extraordinary finds continue to thrill us.A site official added: These colours are intact because they have been buried all these years, but the light and atmosphere will fade them fast unless we protect them.Archaeologists said yesterday that they had discovered a tomb from the nd century BC at the ancient Greek colony of Cumae, near Naples, which predates the Roman empire.Wall paintings in the tomb depict a banquet including a naked slave bearing a silver jug.

title: queensland storm tornado mum battered hailstones
story: Fiona Simpson urged others to be careful after her face and back and her daughters head were hit when the hail broke the windows of their car in Kingaroy in the South Burnett region yesterday.Violent storms caused widespread chaos as they swept across southern Queensland yesterday, tearing roofs from properties and destroying crops just before the harvest season.Sharing photos of their injuries on Facebook, Ms Simpson - who was also in the car with her grandmother - said: I’ve learnt my lesson today, NEVER drive in a hail storm!We parked on the side of the road when the storm got to heavy and the hail blew out our windows.Ms Simpson said she used her body to stop daughter Clara being badly injured.Please, please be careful in this storm season, she said. My entire back, arms and head are badly bruised.The young mum told ABC Brisbane that she originally sheltered the infant in her car seat.But as the hail grew heavier, she unbuckled her from the car seat and held her on the floor near the pedals as it was the only safe place.I could see her, she was screaming, but I couldnt even hear her, it was so loud, she told the broadcaster.Ms Simpson, her daughter and her grandmother were hospitalised, but the mum and daughter have since been released.The powerful super storms and a tornado are part of two weather supercells - sometimes called a rotating thunderstorm due to persistent updrafts - which tore apart towns in Queenslands south east when it ripped through the area this week.According to local media News, hail the size of tennis balls lashed communities in the storm, leaving , without power.In some footage of the storm, violent supersized hail is seen bouncing as it hits the ground in a garden.Farmers have reportedly said their entire crops, including wheat, barely, melon and stone fruit have been wiped out following the storms, while there are reports that lightening has killed some cattle.One Tansey resident Greg Hellmuth told News: The nose was unbelievable.We ran inside and everything was going sideways, all the trees were going sideways.We went under the mattress and thats where we stayed, he said.His we Gail said after the storm passed, it was just devastation.The Bureau of Meteorology said the South Burnett region and other parts of the southeast suffered the  worst of three severe storms, two of them super-cell storms, with two tornadoes also sighted.Bureau of Meteorology forecaster Jonathon Howe said: October is around the time for supercells in south-east Queensland.Windspeeds in central Queensland were recorded at km h with ml of rain expected to fall today - hindering plans for a clean-up.South Burnett Mayor Keith Campbell said farmers who were about to hit harvest season have suffered very signicant losses, with buildings in his area also damaged, and trees “shredded”.“The hail was simply intense when it fell. It was very very prolic. It simply shredded the ears of wheat and barley that was out there to be harvested,” he said.

title: worlds oldest human koku istambulova curses allah living so long
story: Koku Istambulova, , has lived through two world wars, the Russian civil war after the Bolshevik revolution, and two Chechen wars.According to her Russian passport, her date of birth is given as June , , but officials say originals of Koku’s documents were lost during the wars which ravaged her homeland in the early part of this century and there is no way to prove her exceptional age.However, the -year-old has cursed Allah for giving her a long le with little happiness, and has previously said she has not had a single happy day in her le.She asked: It was God’s will. Why did Allah give me such a long le and so little happiness  I would have been dead long ago,not for Allah who was holding me in his arms.”Koku said: “It is hard to live when all who remembered you died long ago. And it is very scary to die, however old you are.If her age is correct, Koku was  at the time, having earlier lived through the coronation of the last tsar Nicholas II two days before her th birthday - and his toppling when she was .Now, in lucid and deeply shocking testimony, she has spoken of the day her native Chechen people were deported by Stalin to the steppes of Kazakhstan almost  years ago.She told how people died in the cattle-truck trains - and their bodies were thrown out of the carriages to be eaten by hungry dogs.“It was a bad day, cold and gloomy,” she said of the February morning in  when the entire entire nation was banished from their mountain homeland in the Trans-Causacus.She said: “We were put in a train and taken, no one knew where. Railway carriages were stuffed with people - dirt, rubbish, excrement was everywhere.”Young Caucasus girls died from rupturing their bladders as they were ashamed to go to the toilet in crowded stinking the crowded trains, yet there was worse to come.“On the way to our exile, dead bodies were just thrown out of the train,” she said.“Nobody was allowed to bury the dead. Corpses were eaten by dogs. My father-in-law was thrown out of the train in this way.”The paranoid Stalin alleged the Chechens were collaborating with the Nazis and they were told they were bad people and thats why they had to leave, Koku says.“I dont know what we suffered for… I felt no guilt, she said.Koku suffered devastating personal bereavements in her Kazakh hell - her two sons both perished in the harsh conditions, as there were no doctors, no-one to treat them,” she said.“When women gave birth children often died because there were no obstetricians, only neighbours and friends.”Weeping the old lady said: “I only kept my daughter Tamara.”Exile in Kazakhstan was  years - then, after Stalin’s death, people were allowed toto their homeland.When she got back, many houses had been grabbed by incoming Russians - so she set to work building her own home, complaining her husband was too lazy for the work.Previously, Koku has been quoted saying that she is the oldest person who ever lived - yet she has not had a single happy day in her le.Now she admits: “Youre askingI had a single happy day in my le. It was the day when I first entered my house.It was very small and I stoked the stove with wood, but it was my home. I built it myself, the best house in the world. I lived there for  years.As a child she remembers playing with dolls made of cloth by her uncle and had red shoes and white stockings bought by her father ate a fair, but these were the first and last nice clothes in her short youth.She said: “Father was ill, then mother was ill. Grandma was ill. I was the oldest, how could I leave them ”She married late when a man was chosen for her from another village, and while she didnt know him at all in the beginning, she grew to love him.“What  could I doI got married  I had to endure. His name was Magomed and he was younger than me... He wasnt handsome at all, she laughs.The state pension fund, a state body, claims there are  people over  years of age in Russia yet all these claims, including Koku’s, are impossible to very because of the lack of reliable birth or early childhood written records.The oldest documented human lespan is Jeanne Calment, from France, who lived  years,  days, dying in .

story: Amid fears of power outages in such a scenario, ministers have admitted they will need to take action to keep the lights on in Northern Ireland with "contingency planning work" already underway.It has previously been reported one Whitehall plan could see thousands of electricity generators requisitioned at short notice and put on barges in the Irish Sea.:: EUROSTAR AND EUROTUNNELTrains from the UK to European countries could stop without a Brexit deal.The government says it would have to negotiate new agreements with EU countries to maintain cross-border services.Ministers are seeking fresh arrangements with France, Belgium, the Netherlands, and Ireland. They want mutual recognition of documentation so that train operators from the UK and EU can continue to run cross-Channel services.However, passengers are warned they are responsible for ensuring their insurance and tickets are sufficient to cover possible disruption beyond March next year.It means some might want to buy more expensive fares for flexible services, rather than cheaper fixed tickets.:: NETFLIX AND SPOTIFYBritons could lose access to online entertainment services such as Netflix or Spoty while travelling in the EU after a no-deal Brexit.EU rules introduced last year means citizens can access accounts that have been set up in one country while in other member states. However, a government paper warns: "The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU."This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation."UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU.":: TRADEWithout a Brexit deal, the UK will no longer benefit from free trade agreements the EU enjoys with more than  non-EU countries.To compensate for this, the government will seek to bring in new trade agreements with non-EU countries from  March next year, or "as soon as possible thereafter" - although it warns these new deals could include "practical changes". A government paper states: "These new agreements will replicate existing EU agreements and the same preferential effects with third countries as far as possible."Ministers and officials are said to be "engaging regularly with partner countries to complete this work".Should these new deals not be in place by Brexit day, trade with these non-EU countries would revert to World Trade Organisation terms, which could see tarfs on some goods.:: DIAMONDSUK firms could lose the ability to trade rough diamonds internationally in the event of a no-deal Brexit.This is because, at the moment, British companies can trade in rough diamonds within the EU and with other countries outside the bloc due to the EUs membership of the Kimberley Process Certication Scheme .If the UK leaves the EU without a deal, Britain will have to seek its own membership of the KPCS.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey"" data-targeting-"" data-tag"" data-component-name"sdc-site-mpu" aria-label"Advertisement" id"mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance""

title: ireland cannot accept brexit backstop time limit republics deputy pm says
story: The issue has become a major stumbling block in negotiations ahead of next weeks crunch EU summit in Brussels, ahead of which the bloc has called for "maximum progress" in talks.The UK government has sought to make any backstop agreement time-limited, but the EU has rejected this.Speaking to Sky News in Galway, Mr Coveney said: "If the issues arent resolved in three years you cant do away with the insurance mechanism."We cant accept a time limit, but we can accept it will only be there unless and until something better is agreed in the future, which is what everyone wants." Asked,implemented, whether the proposed backstop would last months, years or decades, Mr Coveney replied: "With respect, thats up to the British government who need to decide what they want for the future."Meanwhile, also on Friday and speaking in London following a dficult informal meeting of cabinet ministers in Downing Street, Mr Raab admitted the backstop issue is the "one real sticking point" in negotiations as he offered contradictory comments to Mr Coveney.He said: "[The backstop] would have to be finite, it would have to be short and it would have to be, I think, time-limited in order for it to be supported here."What we cannot do is see the UK locked in via the backdoor to a customs union arrangement which would leave us in indefinite limbo, that would not be leaving the EU."Mr Coveney also tempered expectations of a breakthrough on the Irish border backstop over the weekend.

title: sears just what happened to the amazon of yesteryear
story: He rapidly teamed up with Alvah Roebuck, a watch repairman, with the pair launching a mail-order business selling watches and jewellery the following year.By the mid-s they were selling other items, including cars, sporting goods and sewing machines. Mr Roebuck sold his stake in the business shortly afterwards and a new partner, Julius Rosenwald, came on board.Until then, Sears had been focused on rural America, but Mr Rosenwald spotted an opportunity in the countrys fast-growing cities. He opened the groups first department store, in Chicago, in  and, over time, the stores became more important than the mail order business.That is not to say the mail order business did not evolve. In , it produced its first Christmas gt catalogue specically containing toys, called the Sears Wish Book.Gordon Weil, author of Sears, Roebuck, USA, told the Wall Street Journal this week: "At a time when the country was going through the Great Depression, struggling to establish a sense of identity, [Sears] created a sense of security and reliability."The Sears catalogue was everywhere. In an age before there was the internet, it was in some respects the equivalent of a search engine, that united the country."Everyone had access to the same giant catalogue#that had all kinds of things from tools to appliances to homes. It went from there to being the source from which rural America in particular could buy anything it wanted, even though there were no local stores." It was a business that inspired trust among its customers. It was one of the first retailers anywhere to introduce the concept of "satisfaction guaranteed or your money back" and its slogans, which also included "Sears Has Everything", helped create a common sense of purpose among American consumers at a time when US society was a lot more egalitarian.So what went wrong  While some have blamed Amazon, that is rather too simplistic an explanation, although it may have been true in the last decade or so.A likelier explanation is that the shared sense of purpose in America which made Sears great was gradually eroded.

title: campaigners union leaders politicians back
story: NewsHalt on universal credit rollout demanded by campaigners, union leaders and politiciansThe disastrous welfare shake-up is set to clobber millions of hard-up familiesShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsUnite general secretary Len McCluskey demanded an urgent conversation so people can live in dignity "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCampaigners, union leaders and politicians have backed calls for the Government to halt the national rollout of universal credit. The disastrous welfare shake-up is set to clobber millions of hard-up families. Writing for the Mirror, Labour’s most powerful elected politician, London’s mayor Sadiq Khan, called UC “flawed, cruel and harmful”. The leader of Britain’s biggest trade union also backed the Mirror’s Stop the Universal Credit Cruelty campaign. Unite general secretary Len McCluskey said: “We need an urgent conversation about how work is made to pay so people can live in dignity... not punished by the Department for Work and Pensions and pressed into pauperism.  “We need fair welfare to support people, especially the vulnerable, through times of need. “Every right-thinking person in the country should now unite behind the Mirror’s campaign to stop this car crash of a benefit. Scrap universal credit now.” Officials representing some of the poorest in society have also piled pressure on ministers by urging them to think again before the overhaul takes effect nationwide in July. UC is already in operation in parts of Britain. UC rolls six welfare benefits – child tax credit working tax credit jobseeker’s allowance income support employment and support allowance and housing benefit – into a single, monthly payment.  It will be in every Jobcentre for new claimants by December. Around . million existing benefit claimants are due to be “migrated” to UC from July. Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey has defended the scheme but admitted some families will lose out. She said: “We made tough decisions some people will be worse off.” Theresa May’s former deputy Damian Green, who is still close to the PM, said: “The whole point of universal credit is that extra work always pays.” Though he admitted the system will need “tweaking”.  Our campaign proposes three options to halt the misery: redesign UC to be fit for purpose axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable introduce a brand new system. More than , people had signed our petition by last night. Vicki Nash, of mental health charity Mind, said: “Already, far too many people are losing out because they can’t navigate the online system for universal credit or fill out complex and y forms when they’re unwell.” Citizens Advice called for urgent improvements to UC. James Taylor, of disability charity Scope, said: “Universal credit is stockpiling problems that will hit large numbers of disabled people hard when its mass rollout begins.” , families with disabled children will be pound, worse offBy MIKEY SMITH, Political CorrespondentAs many as , families with disabled shychildren could be more than pound, a year worse off under universal credit, a charity warns. An analysis by charity Contact revealed the reforms will result in poundmillion less being spent on disabled kids than under the current system. With UC, a payment known as the “lower disabled child element” has been halved. This applies to all disabled kids except those on the highest rate of the DLA care component and those registered blind. In most cases, only those needing -hour care qualy for the top rate.

title: mp asks government investigate fracking
story: NewsMP asks government to investigate fracking sentence judge who has family links to oil and gas industryJudge Robert Altham jailed Simon Blevins, , Richard Roberts, , and Richard Loizou, , over their demonstration at a Cuadrilla siteShareCommentsByLouie SmithDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT NewsJudge Robert Altham jailed three protesters "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The government has been asked to investigate a judge who jailed three fracking protesters after the Mirror revealed his family links to the oil and gas industry.Judge Robert Altham jailed Simon Blevins, , Richard Roberts, , and Richard Loizou, , over their demonstration at a Cuadrilla site in Little Plumpton, Lancashire. Critics claimed the punishment was “manestly excessive”. Yesterday the Daily Mirror revealed the Altham family business, J.C. Altham and Sons, supplies the Irish Sea oil and gas industry. Now Blackpool South MP Gordon Marsden, whose seat is near the Cuadrilla site where the men were arrested, has asked for clarication from the Ministry of Justice. In formal questions in Parliament, he asked Justice Secretary David Gaukehe will undertake an investigation into compliance with the Judicial Code of Conduct relating to the case. He also asked Mr Gauke to make public whether the judge sought advice from his Department and the Ministry of Justice on the requirements of the Judicial Code of Conduct in relation to family connections.  Mr Marsden said in a tweet that the judge should have excused [sic] himself. The MP told the Mirror: I think it is in the public interest that we should know as soon as possible whether the judicial code of conduct was adhered to by the judge in question at this trial. The controversy regarding the severity of sentencing makes this particularly important in such a highly sensitive and charged situation as fracking. The judicial code of conduct states a judge’s impartiality may be questionedfamily members are “politically active” or have “financial interest” in the outcome of a case.  The judge’s parents John and Linda,  and , are shydirectors of J.C. Altham  Sons. His sister Jane, , is managing director of the firm, which supplies ships’ stores, including food, tools, rigging equipment and clothes. The firm’s website says it is a “specialist supplier to offshore gas and oil s”. In  Jane’s name and that of her firm appeared on an open letter backed by  businesses. It urged Lancashire County Council to permit fracking and create a “poundbillion supply chain”. Judges are expected to tell defence and shyprosecution lawyersthey feel their impartiality in a case may be called into question.  A spokesman for the Judges’ Council said: “There are longstanding principles, set out in case law, which guide how judges approach possible conflicts of interest. They ensure that when hearing a case, a judge will be mindful of possible conflicts of interest and can draw relevant matters to the attention of parties in the case.” Judge Altham did not wish to add anything to the Judges’ Council’s statement when the Mirror first reported the story.

title: stop universal credit cruelty petition
story: NewsStop Universal Credit: Sign our petition against cruel and vindictive Tory benefits cutsThe Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of UC and for a review to take placeShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsTory Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey faces demands to halt such audits "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Mirror is urging our readers to back our petition to stop the rollout Universal Credit which is plunging families into debt and despair and replace it with a fair system. Critics complain UC, merging six benefits into a single structure, is harsher on people both in and out of work and is effectively a near poundbillion welfare cut. Campaigners have said some families could end up pound a month worse off. In its place we want a modern welfare state, helping instead of hurting children .  It comes after former Prime Minister Gordon Brown has described it as a “cruel and shyvindictive” system, warning it will plunge a record five million children below the breadline. Writing in the Mirror Mr Brown said that after  years in politics, he never expected to see poverty and hardship ing on such a terrible scale. His is the most prominent voice to join calls for the system to be scrapped. The Mirror revealed two weeks ago Labour was considering axing the benefit reforms.  Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said on Sunday: “I think we are moving to a position now where it is just not sustainable. It will have to go.” Universal Credit introduced one system to replace six benefits: Child Tax Credit, Working Tax Credit, Jobseekers Allowance, Income Support, Employment Support Allowance and Housing Benefit. When former Work and Pensions Secretary Iain Duncan Smith launched it in  he said that it would make work pay.  But the major problem was that it coincided with billions in Tory benefit cuts making it less generous than its design. Three quarters of claimants struggle with bills - according to the DWPs own figures.  Rent arrears soared pound a head in two trial zones, while food bank use in another area, Hastings, rose %. There have also been concerns raised by charities that paying the money to the head of the household fans the flames of domestic abuse.  While just last week the Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey is said to have admitted privately that millions of families will lose pound a month. In June the National Audit Office warned there is no evidence UC is making work pay and it may never be value for money.  Last year , people failed to get their first payment within a six-week limit. Ministers unveiled pound.bn of improvements in November , cutting the six-week wait to five, but critics say it was not enough. While even Mr Duncan Smith called for another poundbillion to be pumped in. After eight delays UC will only finish its rollout in March .

Mick Tyler, , and fianceacutee Sarah Harmer, , from Snodland near Maidstone, couldnt believe it when they got an email saying theyd bagged the le-changing amount. But when they rang the National Lottery to claim their winnings, the call centre adviser said there had been a mistake, reports Kent Live. Mick explained: “He said ‘oh no, no you haven’t won’. Mick said: “We were like let’s not get completely carried away, so we just had to wait. “It was like, at am we are going to know for definite. “We set our alarms and at am we were straight on the phone. We rang, we spoke to them. We couldn’t believe it. We were on the phone to our family. My family came straight over.  “We skipped a day off work. We were all celebrating all day and we took them all out for a nice lunch and a few drinks.” At the celebration at Reculver Visitor Centre, near Herne Bay, the couple also revealed how they intend on spending their winnings. Sarah said: “We’ve put a deposit down on a new-build house in Snodland. It’s got five bedrooms. It’s going to be ready by March or April .

title: dying mum marry love life
story: NewsDying mum will marry love of le to share same surname as their children so they always remember herMum-of-one Kaylea Callacher was diagnosed with stage  bowel in January - and subsequent treatment was unsuccessfulShareCommentsByChantelle HeedsNeil Murphy:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsKaylea Callacher with her husband and two young sons "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young mum will marry the love of her le after being given the devastating diagnosis that she has just months to live. And the wedding means Kaylea Callacher, , will fulfil a lelong wish share the same surname as her children for the first time. She hopes this will help the youngsters remember her when she is not around any more. Kaylea complained of stomach pains for years - but says doctors told her it was nothing to worry about.In January , she was diagnosed with stage  bowel cancer which had spread to her liver, the Liverpool Echo reported.At the time, her two children were just three and nine months old.  The mum underwent sessions of chemotherapy every fortnight for three months in hope of reducing the tumours - but this was unsuccessful. After having an operation to remove part of her bowel and half of her liver, the teaching assistant thought she had beaten the cancer and was getting stronger each day. Her sister, Sinead Callacher said: At the time, Kaylea’s two beautul babies, Kian and Aoe were just three years old and nine months old. This news, as you can imagine, was very hard to digest. However, Kaylea being the strongest person I know, put up a fight for her family. However, Kaylea started experiencing pain and sickness earlier this month and was admitted to Merseysides Aintree Hospital again on Tuesday. Doctors carried out scans on Wednesday, which revealed that the cancer has ed and is now terminal.  Sinead added: Bringing her scan forward, we heard the news we hoped we would never hear. Kaylea’s cancer is back and this time has spread all over her liver, meaning another operation is out of the question. [We are] now being told there is nothing they can do and she may not make it to see Christmas. Doctors have predicted that Kaylea does not have long left to live, and have advised her to celebrate Christmas next month, which she is hoping to do with her family in a cottage. Kaylea, who is engaged to her partner of  years, Mark McCole, has also announced her final wish is to marry him before she dies. Kaylea thought this wasnt going to be possible, but she has today been announced as the winner of the Liverpool Echos Win a Wedding competition.  It was revealed that Kaylea was a clear winner, after more than one million tokens were submitted in her name by people of Liverpool who were moved by her story. Upon hearing she was the winner of the wedding worth pound,, Kaylea said: We met in the Yates bar in Bootle when we were just , and I just cant explain what this means to us. We have wanted to marry for so long and then we had kids, and then this news. Its amazing - it means the world to us both. The doctors told me to do what I wanted to do, and I will now be able to do both - spend Christmas with my family and marry Mark. The particularly touching reason Kaylea wanted to get married before she passed away, however, was so that she would have the same surname as her children.  She explained: One of the big things is I want my children to have the same surname as me. I want them to realise I was part of their le, even when Im not around anymore. Although there is no cure for the cancer, Kayleas family have launched a fundraising page in an attempt to raise pound, for treatment. Sinead, , set up the page and claims without it my sister might not make it until Christmas. She added: The specialists have gave us one chance but its not through the NHS and its pound, per round. We cant give up on my sister, please I need all your help. The drug, from America, is called Avastin and is used alongside chemotherapy in an attempt to prevent existing tumors growing further.  While the treatment will not cure Kaylea, Sinead hopes it will extend her le by a few more months to give her time with her children. The page was launched just yesterday, and already more than pound, has been raised. Kaylea said: Just do everything you want to do - le is too short. If people are living le better, and loving their friends and family a bit more because of my message, that would make me really happy.

Specialists say the boy, who weighs . kilograms - about seven-and-a-half pounds - suffers near-continuous seizures which are resistant to treatment.  One doctor told Ms Justice Russell that the little boy has a low level of awareness but can feel pain and has been seen to grimace. Specialists said the burdens of treatment outweigh the benefits. title: royal wedding superfans who camped
story: NewsRoyal wedding superfans who camped out for THREE NIGHTS to see Eugenie find little competitionEven though Princess Eugenie is only ninth in line to the throne, and the crowds were thinner than on her cousin Harry’s big day in May, Britain’s most dedicated royal well-wishers saw out the day in styleShareCommentsByOliver MilneHelena Kelly:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMirrorman Oliver Milnewith fan David Weeks, , from Petersfield in Hampshire, enjoying the atmosphere at Windsor today "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRoyal superfans began their vigil outside Windsor Castle on Tuesday night to get a glimpse of Princess Eugenie on her big day. Even though she is only ninth in line to the throne, and the crowds were thinner than on her cousin Harry’s big day in May, Britain’s most dedicated royal well-wishers saw out the day in style. Dressed head-to-toe in a union jack suit Joseph Afrane, , said he came to pay tribute to a country who had saved his le  years ago when he came from Ghana as a refugee. He said: “The Queen is our head of state and this is her granddaughter - we should be here for her because she has been here for us, always. Despite the small crowds the royal fans were determined to get the most from the big day - singing the national anthem and ‘get them to the church on time’ while wrapped in flags.  A dedicated core who had slept out since earlier in the week to get the best spots found that they didn’t face much competition for the best spaces. But they say the time is all part of the atmosphere for them - letting them soak up the spirit of the day and swap stories of better attended royal events in the past. For -year-old Terry Hutt from Weston-Super-Mare getting a glimpse of the royal couple meant sleeping out on the street last night. “I’ve been coming to every royal event I could for the last  years, I wasn’t going to miss this,” he said. “Obviously the level of excitement isn’t quite what it was for Harry and Meghan’s wedding but it is our royal family and more people should be here to support them “Eugenie looked beautul in her dress.” Some braved the cold for even longer.  Kerry Evans, , from Barton-Upon-Humber arrived on Tuesday and has camped out since. She said she came to pay tribute to a family who she said gave her strength when she raised her two autistic sons. She said: “Looking at the royals I’ve always seen a family that looked like mine and I have always taken a lot from that. “Big crowds or not, it was a gorgeous day and I wouldn’t have missed it for the world.” But not everyone felt they got the most from their hours of waiting outside Windsor Castle’s walls. One man who had been waiting for three days to see the carriage procession said he was “thoroughly disappointed”. Bartly Graham, from County Durham also arrived on Tuesday.  The -year-old said: “I did Harry and Meghan’s wedding and it was a much larger affair. “I’m thoroughly disappointed that we didn’t have the general horse displays and the military aspect, I’m really disappointed.” But the mood for these most dedicated fans was summed up by American Maggie Doyle, , who came all the way from Brussels where she studies to watch the day unfold. She said: “She could be the th in line to the throne and I’d still be here! “I thinkI was British I would be frustrated though, knowing my tax was funding this.”

title: weekend weather forecast storm callum
story: NewsWeekend weather forecast: Storm Callum to batter UK with mph winds and downpoursA business group has warned the bad weather could cost the economy as much as £ millionShareCommentsByMirror:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video met-office-weekend-weather-report-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Storm Callum is set to unleash mph winds and downpours across the UK this weekend.An amber weather warning has been issued across Scotland, Wales, southern, western and northern England by Government environment officials ahead of the severe storm. And a business group has claimed the bad weather could cost the economy as much as pound million. The impact of cancelled flights, trains and standstill traffic means that firms could lose out on delayed deliveries and stranded staff.Met Office meteorologist Matthew Box said: On Saturday there will be rain pushing into South West Wales, parts of Ireland, England and Scotland.For Saturday, the Met Office has issued an amber rain warning for South Wales and very strong winds on Saturday. There is a risk of floods and risk to travel so I advise everyone keep updated with local weather reports, he continued. Areas such as South West Wales, Cornwall and Devon will see very strong gusts on Saturday morning. Winds will reach up to mph. Conditions are expected to improve by Sunday with dry sunny spells during the day but possible showers in the north later on.  Today hundreds of homes have been left without power, falling trees and high seas are causing major disruption with weather warnings expected to remain in place until Saturday evening. Roads across Devon have been blocked by debris and standing water as flights and trains cancelled in the face of winds at more than mph and up to a weeks rain falling in a few hours. All CrossCountry trains are stopped in and out of Devon - not passing beyond Exeter or Plymouth so they do not cross the Dawlish sea wall. Falling trees caused delays for passengers in Plymouth and Cornwall this morning. Flybe cancelled all flights in and out of Exeter until this afternoon when the weather was expected to improve.  Tim Jones, chairman of the South West Business Council, said: With an extreme weather event like this, we reckon that the impact on business to be around pound million in terms of access to work and fracturing the supply chain which relies so heavily on just-in-time deliveries. The greatest rupturing is still on our road network, the fragility of having just one single artery, the M, into the region is exposed when we have bad weather. Mr Jones said that air travel has remained the most resilient in the face of bad weather but the resilience of the railway remains a priority for economic leaders. He said: This re-emphasises the impact of the vulnerable Dawlish sea wall and other flood prone areas, like Cowley Bridge.

title: mystery giant worm canadian mountains
story: NewsMystery of giant worm in Canadian mountains solved  years after being spotted on satelliteThe odd shapes emerging from the forest have been revealed as man-madeShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video what-massive-worm-like-structure-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe mystery surrounding a huge worm-like structure spotted on a satellite image more than a decade ago has been solved. First seen by the Quickbird Two as it travelled over the Canadian wilderness in September , the image confused many experts. The photos showed giant worm-like structures emerging from the forest, according to the Science Channel. Biologist Rob Nelson said: It really looks like some writhing of white worms. Theres no obvious beginning or end. Just how big are they   Andrew Robertshaw, a military historian, while looking at the image, said: It doesnt show anything that makes any logical sense. But a closer look at the image showed a large rectangular man-made structure that was the key to the mystery. An inspection on the ground showed the worms were actually massive piles of rock and gravel.  They would pick up gold bearing gravel, washes out and collect the gold out, before throwing the waste out the back. In turn creating weaving, lines of gravel that appear to emerge from the ground. And the huge structure was actually a massive dredging machine.

story: NewsIndonesian tsunami: Mum who survived says her mother was swallowed as ground opened around themEXCLUSIVE: Rori Oryza, , was with family members when a . magnitude quake triggered the giant waveShareCommentsByTom Parry:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsRori Oryza, , with her baby "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who survived the Indonesian tsunami has told how her mother was swallowed up as the ground opened around them. Her -year-old grandmother, cousins, niece and aunt have also yet to be traced. Her home has been destroyed. title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have been applied to his dad’s old team.”The fans also pointed out should the Killie player who ed to win the kick, Jordan Jones, be handed a two-game ban, that in itself could damage Dundee.The games he would miss would be against St Mirren and Hamilton, the two sides immediately above the Dark Blues at the foot of the Premiership.SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell was copied in when the letter was e-mailed and has promised a response will be given.

story: A FIFE man has created his own mini marvel of engineering in the shape of a replica Forth Bridge in his back garden.When Paul Hewitt bought his Glenrothes home, the little burn flowing through the grounds was a big part of its appeal.In a remarkable labour of love,  Paul has lovingly created an ft long replica of the Forth Bridge, complete with lights.He said he was pretty proud of his handiwork.Paul, , who served his time as a plater, fabricated the model marvel of Victorian engineering himself from scratch.A couple of his friends who are welders then helped him join the model bridge together.The resulting construction has become an unlikely internet sensation.“It’s a real talking point, and from the reaction on Twitter I’ve not heard of anyone  who has done something like this,” said Paul.“I even got a comment from the Forth Bridges about the type of paint they use,I wanted to paint it the same colour.”But Paul insisted he was not going to build any more bridges.“It’s a real talking point, but I’ve no plans for anything ,” he said.

title: Age proves no barrier to degree success
story: An Inverness grandfather proved that age is no barrier to academic success when he graduated from Inverness College UHI along with more than  fellow students.Hugh MacKintoshgraduated with a : BAin business and management with human resource management, following in the footsteps of his daughter Tara, who graduated from the same course in .Former Scottish Government business manager Mr MacKintosh, who lives in Inverness and enjoys spending time with his we Carole and -month-old granddaughter Ava, retired from his civil service role in  and had worked in Go Outdoors before deciding to study full-time."I never got the opportunity to go to university when I left secondary school in ," he said."I got married and had a successful career in the civil service for  years."But getting a degree was something I had always wanted to do. Retirement gave me the opportunity, but also the fact that the course was offered by a university on my doorstep."Mr MacKintosh believes his experience of working in business helped him and his fellow students through their studies."I really enjoyed the course," he said."My IT skills werenrsquot as hot as some of the younger studentsrsquo, but I was able to balance that out with my practical experience working in a business environment, and we all supported each other in dferent ways."I was always made to feel very welcome and my fellow students and tutors were so supportive."Irsquom happy in my retirement knowing Irsquove got my honours degree."That was what I was desperate to do."Also graduating was student representative Donna MacAngusfrom South Kessock, who achieved an HNC in events.She combined her studies with raising her five children and working in the food and beverage team at the college.She previously studied events and hospitality operations and is now aiming for a degree in events management."I have gained so much experience in dferent types of events and gained more confidence in myself and my abilities," she said."The course has provided a range of opportunities to gain experience in the workplace and itrsquos been wonderful through my studies to be able to volunteer at events including NessCon and Gok Wanrsquos Fashion Brunch Club."My time at Inverness College UHI has been amazing so far. The staff have all been fantastic and are always there to help when you need it."You are never alone ndash there is always someone there to help."As well as students celebrating the culmination of years of study, special awards were also presented at the ceremony.Among the recipients was Rachael Bewsfrom Evanton, who was named the collegersquos Alumnus of the Year.The award is given annually to a graduate who has made an outstanding contribution to their community or has made signicant achievements in art, science or business or in public or academic le.Having graduated with a first-class honours degree in business and management in , she has gone on to specialise as a digital marketing consultant.In February she founded ALICAS, a social enterprise based in Edinburgh which gts bespoke parcels of clothing to women who have fled abusive relationships.The packs are created using surplus retail stock which would otherwise be sent to landfill or incinerated.Ms Bews was awarded an RSE Unlocking Ambition Enterprise Fellowship, supported by CREATE, UHIrsquos centre for enterprise and innovation."The University of the Highlands and Islands played a formative role in sparking my passion for and experience of enterprise and entrepeneurship," she said."I couldnrsquot be more delighted to continue working with the university and CREATE on my new venture, ALICAS."With the continued support of the university and CREATE, it is now my ambition to create a scalable business model, designed to support as many women as possible."Professor Chris OrsquoNeil, principal of Inverness College UHI, urged the students to enjoy their chance to celebrate with their friends and family."It is my great pleasure to congratulate every single student graduating," he said."Graduation is a particularly special time as we celebrate and recognise the successes and achievements of our students in the presence of the people they care about most."It is reward and recognition of their hard work and commitment and I am very proud to share in this moment."I wish them only continued success as they bring to a close one chapter but embark on another, which Irsquom sure will include interesting and rewarding careers."Friday  Oct  : PM

title: Dance event raises charity cash
story: An Inverness school worker has raised thousands of pounds for charity by holding a second -hour dance event.Claire Fishertook on the danceathon at the Florians Theatre to raise money for Cancer Research UK.She decided to complete the challenge for a second time after the death of her father. Her mother is also battling cancer.Donations have so far topped pound.Mrs Fisher was joined at the danceathon by  fellow fundraisers, who danced for periods of six, eight or  hours, as well as members of the public who came along to support her ndash with some even joining in the fun."It went really well," she said."It was a bit grim at times which is to be expected when you are on the go for  hours but it was a lot of fun."We are still taking donations. We have raised about pound so far which I am so happy about, and a couple of people are doing some more things in the next couple of weeks, so we could get up to the pound mark."We are so tired ndash in my family we have been a household of zombies because it was so tough ndash but it was definitely worth it."Mrs Fisher is already planning a repeat of the event next year, and wants to make it even bigger and better to encourage more people to get involved."People are already askingthere is going to be another one next year," she said."We are going to do one, because there are so many people who are now wanting to get involved."We started with three people last year, expanded to  this year and now so many people are getting in touch."We want to make it even bigger next year and get as many people involved as possible."Friday  Oct  : PM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Friday  Oct  : PM

title: New festival promises a feast of folk talent
story: A NEW music festival will be added to Invernessrsquos already jam-packed programme of summer events next year.Organised by the same team that puts together the popular Groove dance music event The Gathering will concentrate on more traditional sounds when it comes to the cityrsquos Northern Meeting Park in June.Billed as a celebration of the best of Scottish talent Tide Lines, a band that has already racked up more than three million steams for their singles online, have been confirmed as headliners.They will be joined on Saturday, June  by The Vatersay Boys, Elephant Sessions and
